editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: DUPLICITY: A COMEDY. AS IT IS PERFORMED AT THE THEATRE-ROYAL, IN COVENT-GARDEN.
LONDON: Printed for G. ROBINSON, PATER-NOSTER ROW.
TO THOMAS HARRIS, ESQ. THIS COMEDY IS INSCRIBED, AS A PUBLIC ACKNOWLEDGEMENT OF THE ADVANTAGES IT RECEIVED, FROM HIS GREAT ATTENTION AND TASTE, AS A CRITIC,

closer.signed: BY HIS MOST OBEDIENT, HUMBLE SERVANT, THOMAS HOLCROFT.

div.head: PREFACE.
div.p:
SINCE it is the fate of dramatic works to undergo a much more ſevere ſcrutiny than any other of the efforts of the mind; authors, in this predicament, are juſtifiable in taking every opportunity of ſpeaking in their own behalf, and the egotiſm ſhould be, and is, by the candid, readily forgiven them. The applauſes beſtowed upon DUPLICITY, in the Theatre, have equalled my fondeſt hopes; and ſelf-love itſelf cannot accuſe the auditors of ingratitude, or want of penetration. But though there are ſcenes happy enough to have given univerſal ſatisfaction, there are others that have been called vulgarities, damned ſtuff, and by other conciſe and ſummary epithets, which men accuſtomed to decide without deigning to reaſon, have invented and appropriated to their own proper uſe. I do not mean to affirm there is no truth in theſe remarks: I am, perhaps, the perſon leaſt qualified of any to pronounce, with ſafety, on the merits or demerits of the work. Fathers, who are the moſt free from prejudice, cannot ſee
thoſe defects in their offspring, which are obvious to others. In the rapidity of compoſition, blemiſhes are ſuffered to eſcape, through a laudable attention to things of greater importance; and, like an ugly face, preſently become too familiar to be diſguſting. It is, for this reaſon, dangerous to commit any thing to paper, which the judgment, at the firſt perception, condemns. A work of any conſequence is read and reconſidered ſo repeatedly, that the ideas at laſt loſe both novelty and force, and the writer is diſguſted to find thoſe things, which, when firſt conceived, gave him ſo much pleaſure, become vapid, and aſſume the appearance of common place. For theſe reaſons, I ſay, it would be arrogant in me to ſpeak decidedly; I can only alledge what were my original motives for writing as I have done.

The Engliſh Comic Drama has long been renowned for humour; and when, about fourteen years ago, the French Comédie Larmoyante, or, as we call it, Sentimental Comedy, was introduced, the complaint was, that we had loſt all the ſpirit of our old writers, and were dwindled into mere tranſlators. The town was in this temper when Dr. Goldſinith's Comedy of SHE STOOPS TO CONQUER was produced, in which, humour, alone, ſeems to be the chief intention of the Author, and which gave a fatal blow to mere ſentimental dialogue. The ſucceſs of this
piece rouzed later writers from the ſoft ſlumbers of the heart, and wit and humour became commodities in great requeſt. The road to fame, though difficult, was obvious; and it would have been unpardonable for a young traveller, at his firſt out-ſet, ſo far to have miſtaken, as not to have attempted it. The difficulties and dangers have increaſed, however, in a vaſt proportion. I need only mention the SCHOOL FOR SCANDAL; and every diſcerning critic will immediately recollect how, and why.

In the Comedy of DUPLICITY, the 'ſquire and his ſiſter are characters that, in their own nature, cannot admit of delicate ſtrokes; and, if I have erred, it is not, I believe, ſo much in the colouring, as in the choice of my ſubject. An Author in his firſt attempt, is ſeldom impreſſed with that awe for the Public which is requiſite, but ventures many things, that, perhaps, have their excellencies in reading, but that appear rude, abrupt, or indelicate, when pronounced before a large aſſembly. Were the humour of Smollet, which never fails to excite laughter in the cloſet, ſpoken upon the ſtage, it would frequently excite univerſal diſguſt. Characters of broad humour are become peculiarly hazardous, becauſe they are become far leſs frequent. A ſenſe of propriety ſpreads in proportion as people read, and reading is an infallible conſequence of riches. This produced
duces delicate ſenſations in thoſe who have acquired ſuch a ſtrict ſenſe of propriety, and they are offended when they ſee things repreſented on the ſtage which, they ſuppoſe, do not exiſt in real life; though there are a thouſand living characters, a thouſand incidents at which, if exhibited, an audience would revolt, merely on the ſcore of improbability.

Whatever the execution may have been, the intention of this Comedy is of a far nobler nature than the mere incitement of riſibility: the vice it pretends to correct is become truly enormous; and I would rather have the merit of driving one man from the gaming-table, than of making a whole theatre merry.

I have, likewiſe, been accuſed by ſome of imitation, and want of originality. It is ſaid, I have ſtolen an incident from one piece, and a character from another, and that it is evidently the play of a player. This laſt remark, I believe, would never have been made, had I not been known to be a player. The accuſations, which have the greateſt appearance of truth, are, that LE DISSIPATEUR of Monſieur Deſtouches, and the Tragedy of THE GAMESTER, have furniſhed the great outlines of the plot. To theſe I anſwer, that, were it ſo, I would make no ſcruple of avowing it, becauſe I ſhould not think myſelf degraded by the avowal; but I declare the plot was finiſhed, and almoſt the comedy,
before I ever read LE DISSIPATEUR: and if I have pillaged the GAMESTER, it was from latent ideas, of which I am unconſcious; for I have neither read, nor ſeen the GAMESTER for many years. A parallel circumſtance to that of Sir Harry loſing his ſiſter's fortune, is found, I am told, in the GAMESTER; but this incident was added to DUPLICITY ſince it was firſt written, by the advice of a friend, to give a ſtrength to the denoument. But there is a ſtory told in the life of Beau Naſh, which, had theſe critics known, would have immediately pointed out the place whence, they might have ſworn, without the leaſt ſuſpicion of perjury, I had ſtolen my plot; and yet, had they ſworn, they would have been perjured, for I never read that ſtory till I had written my Play, and then, I confeſs, I was amazed at the ſimilarity.

However, I repeat, had I taken my plot from any play or ſtory, I ſhould have made no ſcruple to confeſs it, becauſe I think it no diſgrace. The firſt of all poets invented none of his plots; I ſhall never be the ſecond, and yet I affirm I did invent mine; that is, as far as I myſelf am conſcious. The elegant Biſhop Hurd, in his diſcourſe on Poetical Imitation, has the following remark, among many others, which is applicable to the preſent occaſion: The objects of imitation, like the materials of human knowledge, are a common ſtock which experience
furniſhes to all men; and it is in the operations of the mind upon them that the glory of poetry, as of ſcience, conſiſts. Here the genius of the poet hath room to ſhew itſelf, and from hence, alone, is the praiſe of originality to be aſcertained.

The Comedy is now committed to the impartial judgment of the true critic; and I have only to wiſh, it may receive as favourable a ſentence from him, as it has already experienced from the voice of an indulgent Public.

sp.l: RASH was the wight, who firſt, in hollow'd tree,
Daring, reſolv'd to tempt the treach'rous ſea!
Hungry the wretch, who, forth from ſhelly cloiſter,
Firſt drew and ſwallowed down—a living oyſter!
But far more raſh and daring is THAT wight,
Who, in this poliſh'd age, attempts to write:
Long may his hunger laſt, who pines for fame,
Who ſeeks that hard-earn'd morſel, call'd—A NAME!
A morſel clos'd within a ſcaly guard
Of critic ſhells, obdurate, rough, and hard!
Well fare the bard, whoſe fortitude, ſedate,
Stands, unappall'd, before impending fate;
When cat-call-pipers, groaners, whiſtlers, grinners,
Aſſembled, ſit to judge of SCRIBBLING SINNERS!
What mortal mind can keep its terrors under
When gods ſit arm'd, with awful—wooden thunder?
What heart, ſo brave, can check its palpitation,
Before, the grave diſpenſers of damnation:
Or who, in danger of ſuch mighty evil,
Would not turn Indian, and adore the devil?
Various have been the ſtratagems and wiles,
Diſplay'd in prologues, to obtain your ſmiles.
Some make the ſtage an inn; and hope to bribe,
With curious feaſt, the turtle-eating tribe:
Make vain attempts, in metaphor, to treat,
But metaphor is unſubſtantial meat.
So bold harpooners, if their oars ſhould fail,
Toſs out an empty tub, to amuſe the whale.
Others more mean, implore, in whining ſtyle,
That tender pity may your hearts beguile;
Beſpeak applauſe, by way of deprecation,
And think that fame is charity's donation.
So daſtard curs provoke the maſtiff's bite,
Then fawn and cringe to ſhun th' unequal fight.
Our author hopes, by honeſt means, to gain
Plaudits which merit never aſk'd in vain:
Should ſuch bieſt claim be his, he need not fear,
He knows your candour;—Party dwells not here!
Patient to your deciſion he'll ſubmit,
Nor wiſh to bribe the arbiters of wit.

div.head: SCENE I. Sir HARRY PORTLAND's Houſe.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: WELL, my dear Meliſſa, you will be a happy woman!

sp.speaker: Meliſſa.
sp.p: I have no doubt of it. The attention which Mr. Oſborne has ſhewn me, was not that of a man eager to gain the affection of his miſtreſs by humouring her caprices, praiſing her beauty, and flattering her follies. He is obliging and well-bred, but ſincere; yet his diſapprobation is delivered with a delicacy that makes it more agreeable than ſome people's compliments.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: If time, inſtead of mellowing the ſtrokes, ſhould wear away this ſmooth varniſh and diſcover a harſh outline, ſhould you not be offended at the ſeverity of his manner, think you?

sp.speaker: Meliſſa.
sp.p: Believe me, dear Clara, there is no danger; for if there be one man on earth more capable of making a woman happy than another it is Mr. Oſborne.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: It would be hereſy in you, my dear, to hold any other opinion; and I have no doubt but you will continue orthodox after marriage.

sp.speaker: Meliſſa.
sp.p: Yes—I ſhall certainly die in that faith.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Your brother, Sir Harry, I believe, is of your religion too.

sp.speaker: Meliſſa.
sp.p: Entirely—The friendſhip of Mr. Oſborne and my brother is as ſincere as the commencement of it was remarkable—Have you ever heard their ſtory?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Never. You know my acquaintance with your family is but juſt begun; but, I hope, you will not think them words of courſe when I aſſure you that, ſhort as it is, I feel myſelf intereſted in its happineſs.

sp.speaker: Meliſſa.
sp.p: Oh! I am ſure you are ſincere—I know it by ſympathy—Well then, I'll tell you—Harry and Oſborne happened to be both abroad at the ſame time. As my brother was going to Italy, and paſſing through the mountainous part of Savoy, he came to a hollow way, among the rocks, ſurrounded by trees and caverns. All on a ſudden, at a turning in the road, he beheld Oſborne, and his ſervants, attacked by ſix banditti, and ready to ſink under their wounds.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Was Sir Harry alone?

sp.speaker: Meliſſa.
sp.p: He had his governor, two ſervants, and the poſtillion—My brother inſtantly leaped from his carriage, ſnatched up his ſword and piſtols, andflew to the place of action.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: I declare you terrify me!

sp.speaker: Meliſſa.
sp.p:
He was not ſeen by the combatants, and took care to advance ſo near, before he
fired, that he could not fail to do execution—He laid two of the banditti dead; and their companions, who had diſcharged their fire-arms, and beheld Sir Harry's people running to the attack and levelling their pieces, fled.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Thank you for that, my dear—you have given me breath.

sp.speaker: Meliſſa.
sp.p: The intrepidity with which Sir Harry ſaw Oſborne defend himſelf, and the fortitude he diſcovered when he was informed, as it was at firſt believed, that his wounds were mortal, attached my brother ſo powerfully to him, that he reſolved not to leave him in the hands of ſtrangers, but anxiouſly waited while he was under cure.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: This was a noble generoſity!

sp.speaker: Meliſſa.
sp.p: It was; and Oſborne was ſo ſenſible of it that, though he was going the other way, he would return with Sir Harry into Italy; and their friendſhip has continued ever ſince.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: But is it not ſtrange, my dear, that he cannot detach his friend, Sir Harry, from the GAMING-TABLE?

sp.speaker: Meliſſa
sp.p: My brother is inſatuated—It is his greateſt, almoſt his only weakneſs.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: But the report is, that Mr. Oſborne takes advantage of this weakneſs; that, while he publicly ſatirizes the practice, he privately benefits by his ſuperior addreſs; and, in fact, has half ruined Sir Harry HIMSELF.

sp.speaker: Meliſſa.
sp.p: The report of malice, my dear.

div.stage: Enter Sir HARRY PORTLAND and Mr. OSBORNE.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Ladies, your obedient—Pray when did you arrive in town, Madam?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Yeſterday—But how came you to quit Bath ſo ſuddenly, Gentlemen? I underſtood you intended to ſtay another week, and you were gone before me.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Mr. Oſborne, Madam, was horriblement ennuyé—dull as an alderman at church, or a fat lap-dog after dinner—thinking on marriage, Meliſſa, and other momentous matters; and ſo—

sp.speaker: Oſborne.
sp.p: Come, come, Sir Harry, this is mighty ingenious; but you were, at leaſt, as willing to be gone as myſelf—The truth, Madam, is, my MODEST friend, here, heard YOU were to ſet off in a day or two; and, from that moment, was continually giving hints, and aſking me how I, as a lover, could exiſt ſo long without a ſight of my miſtreſs; and, in ſhort, began, all at once, to talk ſo ſympathetically about abſence and ages, that I, who had made the excurſion purely to oblige him, was, I acknowledge, exceedingly happy to find I could oblige him by returning.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: What ſay you to this, Sir Harry?—But, I know your politeneſs—you will confeſs it all to be true, and begin to ſay civil things upon the ſubject, that will only put me to the trouble of bluſhing and curtſying; ſo we'll ſuppoſe them all if you pleaſe—But come, tell me—what's the news of the day?

sp.speaker: Meliſſa.
sp.p: News! Oh, that's true—Look here, my dear!—I thought I had ſomething to tell you— (reads a paragraph in a newſpaper)—We hear, from very good authority, that a hymeneal treaty is concluded between a certain beautiful ward, not a mile from St. James's Square, and her old guardian; and that the lady is expected in town from Bath, every hour, to ſign and ſeal.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: What ſay you to this, Madam?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Say! I proteſt I don't know what to ſay!—except that theſe NEWSMAKERS are a very pleaſant, ingenious kind of people.

sp.speaker: Meliſſa.
sp.p: But a'n't you angry?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Angry! no indeed. I am ſure I am very much obliged to them, for thinking of me—I ſhall be ſo ſtared at—I'll go into public continually, and my guardian ſhall go with me.

sp.speaker: Meliſſa.
sp.p: But is there any foundation for this report, my dear?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Nay, I am ſure I can't tell: there may be, for aught I know—I have ſuſpected the matter a great while, you muſt know, by my guardian's ſimpering and ſqueézing my hand ſo often—then, he is continually talking about METHUSELAH, and the ANTEDILUVIANS, and making ſyſtems to convince me how much ſtronger, and longer lived, ſome men are than others—He read, the other day, in the ANNUAL REGISTER, of a man, at INVERNESS, who lived to the age of one hundred and ſeventeen; and he has been talking, ever ſince, of purchaſing a country ſeat in the HIGHLANDS.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: That would be pleaſant.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Very—Then we ſhould have a flock of GOATS, I ſuppoſe!

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: DORASTUS and FAUNIA.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Oh yes—quite in the DAMON and PHILIDA way.

sp.speaker: Oſborne.
sp.p: You are very happy in a lover, Madam.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p:
Exceedingly—quite proud of my conqueſt—There is no ſuch great miracle in bringing a young fellow, whoſe paſſions are all afloat, to die at ones feet—The thing's ſo natural that one does it every day—But to thaw the icy blood
of a grave old gentleman, to ſee him ſimper, ſigh, dance minuets, and look ridiculous for one—Oh! there is, poſitively, no flattery equal to it.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: He will make your winter evenings in the HIGHLANDS quite entertaining, with relating the wild pranks he committed, and the deeds of proweſs he was guilty of in his youth—then you will be ſo delighted with liſtening to his raptures, and taſting his panada, and—

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Oh yes—yes, yes—ha, ha—I—I think I ſee him now, with his venerable bald head, his ſhrivelled face, and his little pug noſe, that looks as red and as bright as the beſt Dutch ſealing-wax, riſing from his chair, by the help of his crutch-headed ſtick, to breathe forth vows of love and everlaſting fidelity—Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Meliſſa.
sp.p: It's whimſical enough.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Yes—Oh, now you talk of whimſical, I was accoſted by an old gentleman, the night before I left Bath, in the rooms, who was the drolleſt being, and had the moſt agreeable kind of whimſicallity about him, I ever met with—I thought he would have made love to me—ſwore I was an angel, and ſaid a thouſand civil things—quite galant.

sp.speaker: Oſborne.
sp.p: Oh, Madam, the old men are the only polite men of this age.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Upon my word, I begin to think ſo.

sp.speaker: Oſborne.
sp.p: The young ones, taught in the modern ſchool, hold a rude familiarity to be the firſt principle of good breeding.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Manners, like point ruffles, are now moſt faſhionable when they are ſoiled.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: No, no—they only hang the eaſier for being deprived of ſtarch—But who was this old gentleman, pray, Madam?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: A relation of yours, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Of mine, Madam?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: I ſhould ſuppoſe ſo, for he mentioned his nephew, Sir Harry Portland.

sp.speaker: Meliſſa.
sp.p: Our uncle, Sir Hornet Armſtrong.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: It is—I found a letter from him, when I came to town, in which he informed me, he ſhould arrive in Bath the very day we left it.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Who brought this?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: It came by the poſt, Sir.

div.stage: (Sir Harry reads the letter, and ſeems ſurprized.)

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: I die to be better acquainted with him—I muſt have him in my train of ſighing ſwains.

sp.speaker: Oſborne.
sp.p: You ſeem aſtoniſhed, Sir Harry.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Some unkind billet from his miſtreſs, I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: No, indeed; it is the moſt unaccountable epiſtle I ever received, and from my unaccountable uncle too—There, read, read.

sp.speaker: Oſbone.

body.p:
You know, you dog, how your old uncle loves you—You will ſay ſo, when you are thoroughly acquainted with the occaſion of this—In brief—I met with a young lady at Bath, the moſt extraordinary, take her all together, I ever beheld—She is a nonpareil! a phoenix!—But you will judge for yourſelf—She is coming up to town with her brother; who, by the bye, is a country booby—but that's no matter—I ſaw her only once, and that was in the rooms; but once is ſufficient—They intended coming up to London, by way of ſeeing the town, for the are
country people I find, though the ſiſter has more accompliſhments, eaſe and good-breeding, than I ever yet ſaw in the drawing-room—I propoſed a match to the brother, and he ſeemed happy at the offer—They will arrive nearly as ſoon as this, for they ſet out before it; and I ſhall follow, maugre the gout, as faſt as I can.

postscript.p: P. S. I forgot to mention, their name is Turnbull.—

sp.p: TURNBULL! why, what, in the devil's name, is Sir Hornet mad!

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: In one of his right antient whims, I ſuppoſe—Sir Hornet has had many ſuch in his time.

sp.speaker: Meliſſa.
sp.p: But pray, who is this miraculous lady, Mr. Oſborne? for you ſeem to know ſomething of her.

sp.speaker: Oſborne.
sp.p: Do you remember, Sir Harry, a gawky girl, that ſtalked round the rooms, and ſtared prodigiouſly—ſhe that was ſtuck to the ſide of a bobwig'd country 'ſquire?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Oh!—what the—the wench with her arms dangling, her chin projecting, and her mouth open—dreſſed in the—red ribband, tawdry ſtile; and that looked as if ſhe were afraid of being loſt.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Yes—or as if ſhe durſt not truſt herſelf alone, out of her own pariſh, leſt ſomebody ſhould catch her, put her in a ſack, and ſend her for a preſent to the king of the Cannibals.

sp.speaker: Oſborne.
sp.p: The ſame—that is the accompliſhed Miſs Turnbull.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Oſborne.
sp.p: That is the eaſy, well-bred, drawingroom lady.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Is it poſſible?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha, ha,—well— (with an affected gravity)—and I don't doubt but ſhe would make a ſort of a—a—a very good wife—Underſtands the arts of brewing, baking, pickling of pork, curing of hung beef, darning of ſtockings, and other branches of houſewifery, in perfection.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Oh, no doubt—Is perfectly ſkilled too in the ſcience of feeding the pigs.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Yes—and will make her own and her huſband's linen, and do all the needle-work and quilting at home—believes in ghoſts, and has got the wandering Prince of Troy, the Babes in the Wood, and the entertaining dialogue of Death and the Lady, by heart.

sp.speaker: Oſborne.
sp.p: Such, and ſo numerous, are the wifelike properties of MISS BARBARA TURNBULL.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: TURNBULL, too!—Well, that is ſuch a delightful name, for a country lady—ſo paſtoral!

sp.speaker: Oſborne.
sp.p: The father was one of the greateſt graziers in the weſt of England; and was ſo intent on getting money, that he bred his children in the moſt ſtupid ignorance—He is lately dead, and the ſon has commenced gentleman and 'ſquire, by virtue of the father's induſtry, and a pack of fox-hounds; and though he has ſcarce knowledge enough of articulate ſounds to hold a dialogue with his own geeſe, yet does he eſteem himſelf a deviliſh ſhrewd fellow, and a wit—His converſation is vociferous, and patched up of proverbs, and out-of-the-way ſayings, which he ſtrings together without order or connection; and utters, upon all occaſions, and in all companies, without reſpect to time, place, or perſon.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p:
Well, well, Sir Harry, I ſhall have to wiſh you joy ſoon, I ſuppoſe—but I muſt be gone—fifty viſits to make this morning—time flies
—butagreeable company, and all that, you know—Oh, Sir Harry, you mean to attend the ſpring meetings this year, at Newmarket—I am told you underſtand the turf—I think of ſending a venture of five hundred by ſomebody—But I ſhall ſee you often enough before then—Adieu.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Well, what do you think of this lady, Oſborne?

sp.speaker: Oſborne.
sp.p: I think her a very amiable, accompliſhed lady; and one that, under an aſſumed levity, obſerves and underſtands every thing about her.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: I am entirely of your opinion—If I may judge from an acquaintance of ſuch ſhort date, ſhe is the firſt woman in the world.

sp.speaker: Oſborne.
sp.p: Except one, Sir Harry.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: You, Oſborne, may make exceptions, if you pleaſe—I am not ſo captious—She has beauty without vanity, virtue without prudery, faſhion without affectation, wit without malice, gaiety without coquetry, humour—

sp.speaker: Oſborne.
sp.p: Hold, hold—ſtop to breathe—How was it? Vinegar without acid, fire without heat, light without ſhade, motion without matter, and a likeneſs without a feature.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: "Spite—by the Gods!—proud ſpite and burning envy."

sp.speaker: Oſborne.
sp.p: But did you obſerve her Newmarket hint, Sir Harry; and the concealed ſignificance with which it was delivered?

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: I did.

sp.speaker: Oſborne.
sp.p:
Which being faithfully done into Engliſh, bears this interpretation:—"I Clara Forreſter, a beautiful, elegant, ſenſible girl,
with a fine fortune, ſhould like to take you, Harry Portland, with youth, ſpirit, and certain et ceteras, but"—

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: "But that I am afraid of indulging a partiality for any man, who is ſo intolerably addicted to gaming"—Is not that the concluſion of your ſpeech?

sp.speaker: Oſborne.
sp.p: Oh fie! No, no, gaming!—That man has a body without a ſoul, that never felt an inclination to gaming.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Perhaps ſo; but that man has the greateſt ſoul, who can beſt reſiſt that inclination.

sp.speaker: Oſborne.
sp.p: Pſhaw!—;Gaming is the eſſence of faſhion, and one of your ſtrongeſt recommendations—Clara is a girl of ſpirit, and what girl that comes under that deſcription, would ever place her affections on a ſneaking, ſober, prudent fellow—a mechanical ſcoundrel, that knows the day of the month, ſips tea, keeps a pew in the pariſh church, writes memorandums, and goes to bed at eleven o'clock—Poh! abſurd!

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Curſe me, Oſborne, if I know what to make of you—You are a riddle that I cannot expound. You have ſuch an aukward way of praiſing gaming, that it always has the appearance of ſatire.

sp.speaker: Oſborne.
sp.p: Satire! how ſo? Do you think I'd ſatirize myſelf? Who ſports more freely than I do?

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Why there's the myſtery!—You are as eager, to the full, as I am—If I ſet an hundred on a back hand, you offer a thouſand; nay, had I the fortune of a Nabob, and were to ſtake it all, you would be the firſt man to cry cover'd, and be damned mad if any one wanted to go a guinea—Not becauſe you have not generoſity, but in the true and inveterate ſpirit of gaming.

sp.speaker: Oſborne.
sp.p: Certainly—Gaming!—why gaming is the beſt ſal volatile for the ſpleen—It rouzes the ſpirits, agitates the blood, quickens the pulſe, and puts the whole nervous ſyſtem in a continual vibration—No man ever yet died of an apoplexy, that loved a box and dice.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: But they have died as ſuddenly.

sp.speaker: Oſborne.
sp.p: Oh! ay, ay, but that's a faſhionable diſeaſe, an influenza; that's to make your exit with eclat; that's to go out of the world with a good report.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: True—true—and indeed, as to a few years, more or leſs, that is, in reality, a mighty inſignificant circumſtance.

sp.speaker: Oſborne.
sp.p: A bagatelle!—Let us live while we do live, and die when we can't live any longer.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: That's my comfort—that's my comfort—Yes—yes—a piſtol!—a piſtol is a very certain remedy for the cholic—Nobody but a pitiful ſcoundrel would go ſighing, and whining, and teizing other people with his griefs and complaints.—When a man is weary, what ſhould he do but go to ſleep?

sp.speaker: Oſborne.
sp.p: To be ſure—Life itſelf is but a dream—'Tis only ſleeping a little ſounder.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: What! live to be pitied!—Ha, ha—A decayed gentleman! No, no, no—A withered branch—a firelock without a flint—And yet—heigho!—this Clara—damn it—its provoking—Youth—beauty—affability—ſhe's a bewitching girl!

sp.speaker: Oſborne.
sp.p: She is indeed.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: A lovely girl!

sp.speaker: Oſborne.
sp.p: Ay—enough ſo to make any man, that might hope to be in her favour, in love with life.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Any man, any man—but me—no, no—Undone—undone—undone—

sp.speaker: Oſborne.
sp.p: Well but, ſeriouſly, ſince you have ſuch bad ſucceſs, why don't you renounce play?

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Tis too late—I have ſunk eighty thouſand—My reſources almoſt all exhauſted, my eſtates all mortgaged to Jews and ſcoundrels.

sp.speaker: Oſborne.
sp.p: All!

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: All; except the eſtate in Kent.

sp.speaker: Osborne.
sp.p: Well then, if you cannot content yourſelf with your preſent loſs, your beſt way will be to make another vigorous puſh.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: That's exactly what I am determined to do; and, unleſs the devil poſſeſſes the dice, I think I may expect, without a miracle, that fortune ſhould change hands.

sp.speaker: Osborne.
sp.p: One would think ſo, indeed—Will you dine then at my houſe? There will be the Chevalier, the Baron, and the uſual ſet—They have engaged to dine with me—They are ſpirited fellows, and will play for any ſum.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: I don't know—Suſpicion is a curſt meanneſs; and yet, I cannot help having my doubts of ſome among that company—Nay, had you not ſo often aſſured me you were perfectly acquainted with them all—

sp.speaker: Osborne.
sp.p: Why, I tell you again and again, ſo I am—I will be anſwerable for their conduct, and that's more than I would ſay for any other ſet of gamblers upon earth.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Well, well—I'll meet you there.

sp.speaker: Osborne.
sp.p: We dine early—at five.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Agreed.

sp.speaker: Osborne.
sp.p: And then—hey for a light heart, and a heavy purſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p:
No, no,—No light heart for me—I am ſunk—degraded in my own opinion—Gaming alters our very nature—Oſborne uſed to hate it—he was then an open-hearted, generous
fellow—he now appears to have contracted an inſatiable love for money, and a violent deſire to win—he cares not of whom—of me as ſoon as another—Were I in his ſituation, and he in mine, I think I ſhould find an averſion to increaſe his diſtreſs—he knows mine, yet has no ſuch averſion—Perhaps he thinks my ruin certain, and that he may as well profit by it as another—I know him to have the moſt refined and ſtricteſt ſenſe of honour—I have loſt moſt of my money to him, and in his company, and therefore have not been duped out of it.—That is ſome comfort, however.

sp.speaker: Osborne.
sp.p: Well, Mr. Timid, has Sir Harry ſent to you for a further ſupply?

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: Lackaday, Sir, yes!—And a very large ſupply too—He wants 5000l. immediately—Lackaday! I aſked him how he thought it poſſible for me to raiſe ſuch ſums, as he called upon me for every day—reminded him what a bad way his affairs were in, and what an uſurious rate I was obliged to borrow all this money at.

sp.speaker: Osborne.
sp.p: What ſaid he?

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: Lackaday—not much—ſeemed chagrined—ſaid it muſt have an end, one way or another, ſoon; and demanded, whether I could, or could not, raiſe the money—Lackaday—I told him, I was no longer maſter of ways and means; and he ſaid, then he muſt poſitively employ another prime miniſter, for ſupplies he muſt have.

sp.speaker: Osborne.
sp.p:
Why did you tell him that? Go to him, inform him you have met with a tender-hearted
Jew, who knows nothing of the ſituation of his affairs, that will lend him 10,000 directly, if he wants it.

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: Ten thouſand!—on what terms?

sp.speaker: Osborne.
sp.p: Oh, the mortgage of the Kentiſh eſtate.

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: The Kentiſh eſtate!—Lackaday—But ſuppoſe he ſhould go to gaming, and loſe it to ſomebody elſe inſtead of you.

sp.speaker: Osborne.
sp.p: Oh, I'll take care of that.

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: Lackaday—It muſt not be Benjamin Solomons who lends this?

sp.speaker: Osborne.
sp.p: True—no—humph—Iſaac Levi, agent to a private company at Amſterdam.

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: "Iſaac Levi, agent to a private company at Amſterdam"—Lackaday!

sp.speaker: Osborne.
sp.p: Well—go you to him, and inform him that the money ſhall be ready in about half an hour.

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: Lackaday—Good young gentleman—Heaven pardon me, I had like to have ſaid, damn the dice—You'll be a true friend?

sp.speaker: Osborne.
sp.p: Be under no apprehenſions—This old fool is become ſuſpicious, I muſt be ſudden

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: Had not we better inform him of all, before he goes any further?

sp.speaker: Osborne.
sp.p: By no means—leave that to me.

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: Lackaday—Well—The remembrance of a good deed is grateful on a death-bed.

sp.speaker: Osborne.
sp.p: Do you be expeditious—I'll inſtruct the Jew, and he ſhall meet you here.

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: Heaven pardon me! I had like to have ſaid, damn the Jews.—

div.head: SCENE continues.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: HEAVENS what romance! I can ſcarce believe my eyes—Did you ever hear of ſo ſtrange an affair?

sp.speaker: Meliſſa.
sp.p: Strange! it's miraculous—Quixotiſm!—And our good uncle is the prince of madmen.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: To ſend a fooliſh, illiterate, country dowdy, and her block-headed brother, a viſiting on ſuch an errand—What can I ſay to them? I declare, I don't know how to behave—Never was ſo embarraſſed in my life—Where are they?

sp.speaker: Meliſſa.
sp.p: He has made an acquaintance with the groom, and is gone to the mews, which ſeems to be his proper element, to examine the horſes; and I left her with my woman, ſtaring, like a Dutch doll, at every thing ſhe fixed her eyes on—Here ſhe comes.

sp.speaker: Miſs Turnbull.
sp.p: My gracious!—Here be a power of vine— (ſtaring about). I wonder if that be he that be to be my huſband.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: I hope, Madam, the fatigue of your journey has not injured your health.

sp.speaker: Miſs Turnbull.
sp.p: Zir!

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: I hope you are pretty well after your journey.

sp.speaker: Miſs Turnbull.
sp.p: Pretty well thank you, Zir—iveck he's a handſome man.

sp.speaker: Meliſſa.
sp.p: I don't know what to ſay to her—I am afraid, Miſs Turnbull, you won't find the town ſo agreeable as the Elyſian fields of Somerſetſhire

sp.speaker: Miſs Turnbull.
sp.p: Liſian vields!—There be no zuch vields in our parts—There be only corn vields and hay vields.

sp.speaker: Meliſſa.
sp.p: My brother, madam, means to ſay, You are not ſo well pleaſed with the town as with the country, perhaps.

sp.speaker: Miſs Turnbull.
sp.p: Oh!—Yes but I be tho', and ten times better— (they ſtand ſilent ſome time) Pray, Miſs, when did you zee Zekel Turnbull, my uncle.

sp.speaker: Meliſſa.
sp.p: I have not the honour to know him.

sp.speaker: Miſs Turnbull.
sp.p: My gracious!—What don't you know Zekel?

sp.speaker: Meliſſa.
sp.p: No, indeed!

sp.speaker: Miſs Turnbull.
sp.p: Why, he do come to London zity vour times every year.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Is he in parliament?

sp.speaker: Miſs Turnbull.
sp.p: Parliament?

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Miſs Turnbull.
sp.p: What a parliament-man?

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Miſs Turnbull.
sp.p: No; he be a grazier— (ſilent again) Pray, Miſs, have you been to zee the lions and the wax-work to-day.

sp.speaker: Meliſſa.
sp.p: To-day!

sp.speaker: Miſs Turnbull.
sp.p: Ees.

sp.speaker: Meliſſa.
sp.p: I never ſaw them in my life.

sp.speaker: Miſ Turnbull.
sp.p: My gracious!—What never zaw the kings, and the queens, and the tombſtones?

sp.speaker: Meliſſa.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Miſs Turnbull.
sp.p: Merciful vather!—Well, let's go and zee 'em now then.

sp.speaker: Meliſſa.
sp.p: People of faſhion never go to thoſe kind of places.

sp.speaker: Miſs Turnbull.
sp.p: Never!

sp.speaker: Meliſſa.
sp.p: Never.

sp.speaker: Miſs Turnbull.
sp.p: My gracious!—But I am zure I will go every day, while I be in London zity, if I can vind the way—pray be this vair-time here—Where be all thoſe volk gwain—and where do they all come fro'.

sp.speaker: Miſs Turnbull.
sp.p: I be here.

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: Well, Zir Harry, here we be—Madam, your zervant—I zupped wi Zir Hornet three nights ago, an a zaid you be a vine laſs—What tho'—I had never zeen you, but I gave yo' Miſs in a bumper; an Zir Hornet ſwore, that except Barbara, a didn't knaw one to match you.

sp.speaker: Meliſſa.
sp.p: He did me great honour.

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: Why to be zure a did—What tho'—a was wrong—I zee a was wrong—Barbara is well enough—But what tho'—the greateſt calf isn't always the ſweeteſt veal—Vor all the length of her ſpurs, ſhe won't do, pitted againſt this vine ginger pullet.

sp.speaker: Meliſſa.
sp.p: Your compliments quite over-power me, Sir.

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: Compliments—No, no—What tho'—Vather be dead, an' I ha' three thouſand a year, and the beſt pack of vox dogs in Zomerzetzhire—I a no need make compliments—I would as zoon override the hounds, or vell oak zaplings vor vire wood—Barbara, mayhap, underſtands zic things, her reads kademy o' compliments—vor my part, I a' no time vor zic traſh—

sp.speaker: Miſs Turnbull.
sp.p: I'm zure it be a very pretty book.

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: Hold thy tongue, Barbara, an' then nobody will knaw thee biſt a vool—Lookye me, Miſs—I do want a wife—an' I ſhould like hugely vor you an I to zet our horſes together, as the zaying is.

sp.speaker: Meliſſa.
sp.p: Sir—I don't underſtand—

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: Vor my part, I am none of your hawfbred ones—What tho'—ſhilly ſhally and no thank you are always hungry—A lame tongue gets nothing, and the laſt wooer wins the maid—A bad hound may ſtart a hare, but a good one will catch her.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: I believe, Sir, you never ſaw my ſiſter before.

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: Why, no, to be zure—What tho—Love and a red noſe can't be hid—If you cut up the gooſe, I'll eat it—The hare ſtarts when the hound leaſt expects it.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Very true, Sir—But here is a diſagreeable miſunderſtanding—

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p:
Why to be zure—I do knaw it—We miſunderſtand the thing parfitly well—it be very diſagreeable, an' I be glad of it—I a brought Barbara to London to zee the lions, buy ribbands, an' be married—But what tho'—liking's liking,
an' love's love—myzelf bevore my ziſter—If the mountain won't go to the man, the man mun go to the mountain—an vaint heart never won vair lady.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Don't you think, Sir, that were my ſiſter's affections totally diſengaged, this abruptneſs were very unlikely to gain them? Is it not too violent, think you, for female delicacy?

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: Why to be zure—vemale delicacy!—I hate it—and as vor your abruptneſs, why gi' me the man that ſpeaks bolt outright—I am vor none o' your abruptneſs—what tho'—he muſt a' leave to ſpeak that can't hold his tongue.

sp.speaker: Meliſſa.
sp.p: Your proverb is quite a-propos, Sir.

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: Why to be zure—Dogs bark as they are bred.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Meliſſa.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: I am a ſtaunch hound, Miſs, and ſeldom at vault; an' zo, wi your leave, Ill—

sp.speaker: Meliſſa.
sp.p: I beg, Sir—

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: Nay, don't be baſhful—I like fruit too well to play long at bobcherry—a's a vool indeed that can't carve a plumb-pudding—

div.stage: (Offers to kiſs again, and is prevented by Sir Harry.)

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: I am ſorry to be obliged to inform you, that you are entirely miſtaken, both with reſpect to the affections of my ſiſter and myſelf. As a friend of my uncle's, Sir, I ſhall be happy to ſhew you every reſpect, but nothing farther can poſſibly take place between the families.

div.stage: Enter a SERVANT. (Delivers a card to Meliſſa; ſhe exits.)

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p:
Mr. Timid deſired me to tell you, Sir, that Mr. Levi is quite tired of waiting; and
ſays, if you can't come now, he will call again to-morrow.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Oh, tell him he muſt not go—I beg Mr, Levi's pardon; I'll be with him in a minute. (Exit Servant.)—Sir Hornet has been exceedingly precipitate in this buſineſs, Sir—He is coming to town, and muſt apologize for his error—As to my ſiſter, I have no doubt but ſhe has every reſpect for your merits they deſerve; but her affections are pre-engaged, the nuptials fixed, and are ſoon to be celebrated—While you remain in town, however, I beg you will command my houſe and ſervices.

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: Well, Barbara, what doſt think on un?

sp.speaker: Miſs Turnbull.
sp.p: Why, a be well enough—but I daunt rightly knaw what a means.

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: What a means—thee biſt a vool—thee duſt na knaw the London tongue, thee means—a zaid, in a kind of round-about way, that its all right.

sp.speaker: Miſs Turnbull.
sp.p: Did a?

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: Did a—why to be zure a did—didſt na zee how zivil a were, a what a low bow a made—But thee has no contagion in thee—thee will never learn what's what.

sp.speaker: Miſs Turnbull.
sp.p: Why, where be I to learn zic things—I a never been no where.

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: Never been no where—well—what o' that?—Where have I been? I a never been no where—What tho'—I do knaw how to ſtir my broth without ſcalding my vinger—I can zee an owl in an oven as ſoon as another.

sp.speaker: Miſs Turnbull.
sp.p: But when be us to go and zee the zights?

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: Oh, we'll go all together on the wedding-day.

sp.speaker: Miſs Turnbull.
sp.p: My gracious!—I wiſh it were here.

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: Ay, ay—I daunt doubt thee—women, pigs and poultry be never zatisfied.

sp.speaker: Miſs Turnbull.
sp.p: An be you to be married as well?

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: Be I to be married as well? why to be zure I be—thee biſt a vool, isn't vather dead? an hannot I three thouſand a year, an the beſt pack o vox dogs in Zomerzetzhire? An didſt na hear me tell Miſs 'at I would marry her?—What tho'—I do knaw how to catch two pigeons wi one pea—Shew a dog a bone, and he'll wag his tail—He that is born a beauty is half married, an like will to like.

sp.speaker: Miſs Turnbull.
sp.p: Well then, take me to parliament-houſe, an ſhew me the king, an the queen, and the lord mayor, an th' elephant, an' the reſt o' th' royal vamily.

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: I tell thee, thee ſhatn't.

sp.speaker: Miſs Turnbull.
sp.p: My gracious!—What zignifications my coming to London zity, an' I muſt be moped up a this'n; I will go, zo I will.

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: I tell thee, thee ſhatn't.

sp.speaker: Miſs Turnbull.
sp.p: Why then, an I munnut zee the king—I'll go into next room and zee his picter, that I will—

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: A hoic!—Barbara—Barbara—The helve after the hatchet—He that holds a woman, mun ha' a long rope an' a ſtrong arm—Women an mules will go their own road, in zpite of riders or ſtinging-nettles.

div.head: SCENE II. The Houſe of Mr. VANDERVELT.

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Clara is very beautiful—but mankind is very cenſorious—They will tell me, that ſixtyſeven is too late in life to undertake the begetting, bringing up, and providing for a family—What of that—Muſt I go out of the world, as I came into it—no body to remember me?—Muſt I leave no pretty picture of myſelf?—Sixty-ſeven is but ſixty-ſeven—Have not we a thouſand examples of longevity upon record?—And then—as to cuckolds—I cannot be perſuaded that they are as common now, as they were when I was a youngſter—Times, men, and manners alter—Children are born wittier, and the world gets more ſedate—I myſelf am a living proof of it—I never go to bagnios now—I never break lamps, beat watchmen, and kick conſtables now—Once, indeed, I ſhould have made very little ceremony about dignifying an elderly gentleman, that had a handſome wife; whereas now, I can lay my hand upon my heart, and with a ſafe conſcience declare, I have no ſuch wicked inclinations—

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Ah! mon cher papa! What ruminating!

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Ah! Turtle! But why do you always call me papa? you know I don't like that word, Turtle.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: And why papa, do you always call me turtle?—Have not I told you, fifty times, it puts me in mind of calipaſh—and aldermen—and other ugly animals.

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Calipaſh! Thou art ſweeter, tenderer, more delicate, delightful and delicious, than all the calipaſh and callipee in the univerſe—A gem—a jewel—that all the Sophy's, Sultans, Grand Signiors and Great Moguls, of the whole earth, have not riches enough to purchaſe.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Ah! Mon cher Papa!—You are ſo gallant—You do ſay the moſt obliging things!

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: SAY the moſt obliging things!—Ay and will—No matter—Deeds—Title deeds—Rent rolls—India bonds—Well—Death, and the day of judgment, will make ſtrange diſcoveries.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Oh, yes!—I know you wiſe men often meditate on theſe ſerious ſubjects.

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Ay—Life is treacherous ground—One foot firm, and the next in a pit.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: But why ſo melancholy, papa?

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: I have no friends—that is, no relations—no children—have made a great fortune, by care, and labour, and anxiety, and debarring myſelf the pleaſures, and comforts of life, in my youth—And why ſhould not I ſit down and enjoy it?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Very true, and why don't you?

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Becauſe men are fools, and laugh they don't know why—I hate ridicule—Nobody loves to be thought ridiculous—The world has got falſe notions—A man of fifty is called old, and muſt not be in love, for fear of being pointed at—Whereas ſome men are older at thirty, than others at threeſcore.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: What is threeſcore?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: A handful of minutes!

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: That vaniſh like a ſummer ſhower.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Melt, like a lump of ſugar, in a diſh of tea.

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: That come you don't know how.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: And go you don't know where.

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Surely a man of ſixty may walk thro' a church-yard, without fear of tumbling into a grave?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: If he can jump over it.

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: True—And I was once an excellent jumper—Sixty!—Why Henry Jenkins, the Yorkſhire fiſherman, lived to a hundred and ſixtynine—So that a man of ſixty, even in theſe degenerate days, has a chance to live at leaſt an hundred years.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Well, I declare papa, you are quite a blooming youth!—forty years younger, in my opinion, than you were a quarter of an hour ago!—

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Forty?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: At leaſt!

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Why then, by dad, as thou ſayeſt, I am a blooming youth—Ah turtle!—I could tell you ſomething—that would ſurprize you—I could tell you—Think what I could tell you— (Sings)"If'tis joy to wound a lover"—hem—"how much more to give him eaſe."

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: "When his paſſion we diſcover." (Sings)

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: "Oh how pleaſing 'tis to pleaſe"—Oh I could tell—But no—no—no, no, no—You are ſniggering—laughing in your ſleeve—Ay, ay—I perceive it—You're a wit, and I am an old fool—Sneering—ridiculing me—I hate wit and ridicule.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p:
Me a wit!—Lord, papa—I would not be ſuch an animal for the world—A wit!—Why a wit is a kind of urchin, that every man
will ſet his dog at, but won't touch himſelf, for fear of pricking his fingers.—A wit is a monſter, with a hideous long tongue, and no brains—A dealer in paradoxes—One that is blind, thro' a profuſion of light—A wit is a ſpectre, that makes a pair of ſtilts of his criſs-croſs-row, walks upon metaphor, is always ſeen in a ſimile, vaniſhes if you come too near him, and is only to be laid by a cudgel.

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Frightful indeed!—Thank heaven, nobody can ſay, I am a wit.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Mr. Codicil, the attorney, deſires to ſpeak with you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Very well—I am coming.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Mrs. Trip, Madam, is in the houſekeeper's room, and ſays ſhe hopes your ladyſhip is well.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Deſire her to walk up.

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Who is Mrs. Trip, Turtle?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: A perſon that lived ſeveral years in our family. She is, at preſent, lady's maid to Meliſſa, Sir Harry Portland's ſiſter—She will divert me with her fine language, beſides that, I wiſh to aſk her how ſhe likes Sir Harry's family.

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: I know Sir Harry's uncle, Sir Hornet Armſtrong, very well—an old friend.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Indeed!—I never ſaw him here.

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Why no—I don't know how it has happened, but I have not ſeen him above twice, theſe two years, myſelf—he's an odd mortal—a whimſical old gentleman—well—by, by!

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Adieu!

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: By, by!

div.p: This Sir Harry runs continually in my head—ay, and I am afraid has ſound a place in my heart—yes, yes—there's no denying that—but that FRIEND—that Mr. OSBORNE—Whether it be my particular concern for Sir Harry, or my ſuperior penetration, I cannot diſcover, but that man wears, to me, a moſt ſuſpicious, hypocritical face. (Enter Mrs. Trip) So, Mrs. Trip, how have you done this long time?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trip.
sp.p: Pretty well, thank you, Madam, except that I am ſubject to the hiſtoricals, and troubled with the vapours; being, as I am, of a dilikut nirvus ſyſtem, whereof I am ſo giddy, that my poor head is ſometimes quite in a whirlpool; and if I did not bathe with my lady, the doctor tells me, I ſhould decline into a liturgy, and ſo fall down and die, perhaps, in a fit of apoſtacy.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: And how long have you lived in Sir Harray's family, Mrs. Trip?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trip.
sp.p: I came ſoon after my poor dear lady, your mamma, died, and was interrogated; whereof I was at her funereal—My lady is a very good lady, that is, I mean, Ma'am, my future lady that I live with at preſent—ſhe is to be married ſoon, to Mr. Oſborne, and may Hydra, the god of marriage, tie the Gorgon knot—whereof I heard your ladyſhip is to be one of the ceremonials.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: I am invited, and ſhall be there—But pray, Mrs. Trip, what is your opinion of Mr. Oſborne?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trip.
sp.p: Oh Lord! Ma'am, conſarning Mr. Oſborne—I heard a ſmall bird ſing.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: A ſmall bird ſing!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trip.
sp.p: Yes, Ma'am.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Of what feather was this fowl?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trip.
sp.p: Foul!—No, I aſſure you, your ladyſhip, as fair a ſpeechified perſon as any in England—whereof he has a great valiation for me.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Well.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trip.
sp.p: And ſo the ſecret is, that Mr. Oſborne has won almoſt all Sir Harry's eſtate.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trip.
sp.p: And, moreover, has pretended to be a ſynagogue, and a Jew, and has lent money in other people's names, on morgagees, and nuitants, whereof my friend has been a party conſarned.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Good heaven! what villainy! (aſide) And pray who is your friend, Mrs. Trip?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trip.
sp.p: Oh, Ma'am, I hope your ladyſhip won't intoxicate me on that head, for I know Mr. Timid too well to—

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Oh! it was Mr. Timid.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trip.
sp.p: Why—that is—Ma'am—I didn't mean—Mercy!—What have I ſaid?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: You may aſſure yourſelf, Mrs. Trip, I ſhall be careful not to do you any prejudice.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trip.
sp.p: I am ſure I am ſupinely obligationed to your ladyſhip.

div.p: Poor Sir Harry! He has a heart that does honour to mankind, that does not merit diſtreſs, yet, if I augur right, that muſt ſhortly feel the ſevereſt pangs a falſe friend can inflict!—Ungrateful Oſborne!—I muſt warn Meliſſa to beware of him, and, if poſſible, to detach Sir Harry from the gaming-table.

div.head: SCENE Sir HARRY'S Houſe.
div.stage: Enter Sir HARRY, CLARA, MELISSA, VANDERVELT, laughing.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: HA! ha! ha! Sir Harry, you are a happy man!

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Ay, Sir Harry, you are a happy man!

sp.speaker: Meliſſa.
sp.p: Such an accompliſhed ſpouſe!

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: And ſo kind an uncle!

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Upon my ſoul, I can't help laughing; and yet the more I reflect on the affair, the more I am amazed—Sir Hornet is whimſical, 'tis true, but no fool.

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Fool! Sir Harry!—no, no, he is always the readieſt to ſpy the fooleries of other people—many a time have I laughed at his whims and jokes—an odd mortal he is.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Nay, if he be ſo fond of a joke, who knows but he may have ſent them on this errand, for the joke's ſake,

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: By dad, turtle! thou haſt hit it.—As ſure as can be that's it—it is for the joke's ſake.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Impoſſible—The affair is too ſerious to be intentional caprice.

sp.speaker: Meliſſa.
sp.p: But I thought, when I left you, you were coming to an eclairciſſement.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Coming to an eclairciſſement!—Why I told them, as plain as I could ſpeak, that no alliance whatever could take place between the families.

sp.speaker: Meliſſa.
sp.p: 'Tis certain they have not underſtood you then.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Well, there the matter muſt reſt, till I can find an interpreter, for I can't make myſelf more intelligible.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: And you have not had one tender love ſcene yet?

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Not one—I am amazed at the girl's ſimplicity—it equals her ignorance—ſhe ſpeaks and looks ſo totally unconſcious of impropriety, ſo void of intentional error, that I don't know how to reply.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Suppoſe then you were to practiſe a little—Come, I'll ſtand up for the young lady.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: I ſhall ſtill find a difficulty to ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Surely!

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: In very truth, Ma'am.—But it will be from a quite different motive.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Oh, for the love of curioſity, Sir Harry, explain your motive.

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Ay, Sir Harry, explain your motive.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: I cannot, Sir.

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Cannot! Sir Harry, why ſo?

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: For reaſons, Sir, which are far more eaſily imagined than deſcribed.

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Nay, don't be afraid, Sir Harry.—My turtle knows how to anſwer interrogatories—you won't find her a ſimpleton, I'll warrant.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: No Sir—the danger is that ſhe might find me one.

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: I fancy, Sir Harry, you are a little like me—cautious with the ladies, leſt you ſhould be made ridiculous—I am very circumſpect in thoſe matters.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: You are very right, Sir—It is not every one who has the gift of wearing a fool's cap with a grace.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Ay, but notwithſtanding all this, Sir Harry, I ſhould like to have a love ſcene with you.

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: How, turtle!

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: In the character of Miſs Turnbull.

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Oh!—Ay, do, Sir Harry, have a love ſcene with my turtle—

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Any thing to oblige you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Come then—begin (Clara ſets herſelf in an aukward ſilly attitude) Ah! ha, ha, ha—look! look at my turtle lovidovey!

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: My uncle, Sir Hornet Armſtrong, madam, is deſirous that I ſhould gain the ineſtimable bleſſing of your hand.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Anan!

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Ah! ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: And give me leave to ſay, madam, however unworthy I may be of the happineſs and honour intended me, no perſon can be more ſenſible of them.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: What!—That be as much as to zay, you wunt ha' me, I zuppoſe.

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Ah! ha! ha! ha!—Nay, but don't cry in earneſt, lovidovey.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Oh! dry thoſe heavenly eyes, madam, and believe me, when I call every ſacred power to witneſs my affection—I love, I adore, I die for you—Suffer me to wipe away thoſe pearly tears, that hide the beauties of your cheek

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Sir Harry!

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Ay, hold, hold, Sir Harry!—

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Why ſo, Sir?—'Tis quite in character.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Deuce take you, Sir Harry—You—you are too paſſionate in your feigned addreſſes—So warm and preſſing—

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Ay—ſo warm and preſſing.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: One was not aware.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: I was taken by ſurprize, myſelf, Madam—The bounteous god of love kindly contrived an opportunity, which my profound adoration, and a conſcious want of merit, had totally deprived me of—Pardon me, if, for a moment, I forgot that reſpect which every one, who beholds you, cannot help feeling.

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Why what's this, Sir Harry? You are not in downright earneſt, are you?

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Sincere, as dying ſinners imploring mercy.

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: What in love with my turtle!

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Pooh—Why no, to be ſure—We were only acting a ſuppoſed ſcene.

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Suppoſed!—Bedad, I think it was deviliſh like a real ſcene—You both did your parts very naturally.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Oh, Sir! no actor who feels as forcibly as I do, can ever miſtake his character.

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Feels forcibly!—Your feelings are forcible indeed.

sp.speaker: Meliſſa.
sp.p: Come, come, let us adjourn to the drawing-room; I want to have your opinions on a painting of Coreggio's, that my brother has made me a preſent of.

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Favour me with your hand, young lady—And, Sir Harry, do you take my turtle—but don't you let your feelings be too forcible.

div.head: SCENE II. The Hall in Sir HARRY'S Houſe.
div.stage: Enter Sir HORNET ARMSTRONG and SERVANT, as juſt arrived.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Are the trunks ſafe, ſirrah, George?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: And did you order that dog of a poſtilion to take care of the poor devils the horſes?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: I did, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: And of himſelf?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: I did, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: You did, Sir?—Why then do you go, and take care of yourſelf, you raſcal.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: I will, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: And do you hear, George!

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: If I find you diſobey my orders, I'll break your bones.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: I'll be very careful, Sir, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: Brokerage comes rather heavy, Mr. Scrip, when the ſum is large.

sp.speaker: Scrip.
sp.p: Heavy! no, no—a damned paltry pittance—five and twenty pounds only, you ſee, for ſelling out twenty thouſand—Get more by one lucky hit, than fifty of theſe would produce.

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: Ay!

sp.speaker: Scrip.
sp.p: Oh, yes!—Jobbing—Stock-jobbing, between you and me, is the high road to wealth.

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: Lackaday, may be ſo—Well, good day.
sp.stage: (Scrip is going, but ſeeing Sir Hornet ſtops to liſten.)

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: What, old Lackaday!

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: Ah, Sir Hornet!—

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: What's the beſt news with you?

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: Ah, lackaday, the beſt news I know, is ſcarce worth relating.

sp.speaker: Scrip.
sp.p: Beg pardon, Sir, (To Sir Hornet)—beg pardon—bad news in town, did you ſay?

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Bad, Sir! not that I have heard.

sp.speaker: Scrip.
sp.p: Exceedingly ſorry for it!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Scrip.
sp.p: Never was more diſtreſſed for bad news.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Diſtreſs'd for bad news!

sp.speaker: Scrip.
sp.p: Exceſſively! The reduction of Gibraltar, the taking of Jamaica, or the deſtruction of the grand fleet, either of the three would make me a happy man for life—

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: The deſtruction of the grand fleet make you happy for life!

sp.speaker: Scrip.
sp.p: Compleatly.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Here's a precious ſcoundrel!

sp.speaker: Scrip.
sp.p: No great reaſon to complain, to be ſure—do more buſineſs than any three doctors of the college—Generally of the ſure ſide—Made a large fortune, if this does not give me a twinge—rather overdone it; but any ſevere ſtroke—any great national misfortune, would exactly cloſe my account.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Hark you, Sir!

sp.speaker: Scrip.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: It is to be hoped—

sp.speaker: Scrip.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, it is to be hoped.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: That a halter will exactly cloſe your account.

sp.speaker: Scrip.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: You raven-faced raſcal!—Rejoice at national misfortunes! Zounds! I thought ſuch language was no where to be heard from the mouth of an Engliſhman—unleſs he were a Member of Parliament.

sp.speaker: Scrip.
sp.p: Lord, Sir!—You don't conſider that I am a bear for almoſt half a million.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: You are an impudent villain!—rejoice at the diſtreſs of your country!

sp.speaker: Scrip.
sp.p: Why, Lord, Sir, to be ſure—when I am a bear—There's not a bear in the Alley but would do the ſame—Were I bull, indeed, the caſe would be altered.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: A bull!

sp.speaker: Scrip.
sp.p: For inſtance, at the taking of Charles-Town, no man was merrier, no man more elate, no man in better ſpirits.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: How ſo, gentle Sir?

sp.speaker: Scrip.
sp.p: Oh, dear Sir, at that time I was a bull to a vaſt amount, when, very fortunately for me, the news arrived; the guns fired; the bells clattered; the ſtocks mounted; and I made ten thouſand pounds!—Enough to make a man merry—Never ſpent a happier night in my life!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Aha!—then according to that arithmetic, you would be as merry, and as happy to night, could you accompliſh the deſtruction of this ſaid Britiſh fleet.

sp.speaker: Scrip.
sp.p: Happier, happier by half!—for I ſhould realize at leaſt twice the ſum!—twice the ſum!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Twice the ſum?

sp.speaker: Scrip.
sp.p: Ay, twice the ſum!—Oh! that would be a glorious event indeed! Never prayed ſo earneſtly for any thing ſince I was born—and who knows—who knows what a little time may do for us?

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Zounds! how my elbow aches.

sp.speaker: Scrip.
sp.p: I ſhall call on ſome leading people—men of intelligence—of the right ſtamp.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: You ſhall

sp.speaker: Scrip.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Why then—perhaps you will be able to deſtroy the Britiſh fleet between you.

sp.speaker: Scrip
sp.p: I hope ſo—I hope ſo—do every thing in my power—Oh! it would be a glorious event.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Hark you, Sir—Do you ſee that door?

sp.speaker: Scrip.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: And this cane?

sp.speaker: Scrip.
sp.p: Why, but, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Make your exit, you imp.

sp.speaker: Scrip.
sp.p: But, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Get out of the houſe, you vile raſcal, you diabolical— [Drives Scrip off.] A ſon's ſon of a ſcoundrel—Who is he? What buſineſs had he here?

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: Lackaday, Sir, he is a ſtock-broker, that Sir Harry employ'd, at his ſiſter's requeſt, to ſell out for her; becauſe ſhe chuſes to have here fortune in here own poſſeſſion againſt to-morrow.—I have been paying him the brokerage, and receiving the money, which I ſhall deliver to Madam Meliſſa directly.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: An incomprehenſible dog! pray for the reduction of Gibraltar, the taking of Jamaica, or the deſtruction of the Britiſh fleet.

sp.speaker: Timia.
sp.p: Lackaday, Sir! it is his trade.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Trade! a nation will never flouriſh, that encourages traders to thrive by her miſfortunes—but come—tell me ſomething of my own affairs—Where is Harry—How does he go on?

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: Ah, lackaday!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: What—is he a wild young dog—Does he get into thy books?

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: Ah, lackaday!—Zounds, don't ſigh, man—He won't die in thy debt.

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: Ah, lackaday, Sir Hornet! he ſhould be welcome to the laſt farthing I have in the world.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Should he, old Trupenny!—Then give me thy hand—thou ſhalt be remembered in my codicil—but what—he ſhalt be remembered in my codicil—but what—he ſhakes his elbow I ſuppoſe, hey?—Seven's the main?

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: Ah, lackaday, Sir Hornet! what between main and chance he has been ſadly nicked.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Has he!—I'll ſcore his loſings upon his pate, a dog—that is, if he will let me—But where is Miſs Turnbull?—She'll ſoon reform him, her angelic ſmiles will teach him—

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Sir!—Zounds, you ſtare like the wooden heads of the twelve Caeſars—Miſs Turnbull's charms, I ſay, will find employment for all his virtues, and wean him from all his vices.

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: Will they, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Will they, Sir! Yes they will, Sir.

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: Lackaday!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Lackaday!—What ails you?

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: Nothing, Sir, nothing—only that I am afraid my eyes begin to grow very dim.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Your head, I believe, begins to grow very thick.

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: Ah, lackaday, Sir, like enough—like enough!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Be kind enough to anſwer me a few queſtions?—Is not Miſs Turnbull a beautiful girl?

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: May I ſpak truth?

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: MAY you ſpeak truth! to be ſure you MAY.

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: Then I anſwer, No, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: No!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Is ſhe not an elegant girl?

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Nor a witty girl?

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: No!

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: No!!

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Tolderol lol!—Tititum!—Pray what is ſhe in your opinion?

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: A ſilly, ignorant, ill-bred, country girl, and very unfit for Sir Harry's wife.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Tolderolol—laditum—Let me look in your face—Yes, yes—he has it—the moon's almoſt at full—Poor Lackaday!—which is your right hand?— (Timid holds it up) Indeed! wonderful!—And are you really in your ſober ſenſes?

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: Why, indeed, Sir, I begin to be rather in doubt—I believe ſo—but leſt I ſhould loſe them, I will wiſh your honour a good morning.

div.p:
Lackaday—ha! ha!—Not beautiful—nor witty—nor—tolderol lol—The old fool has a mind to ſet up for a wit, and has began by bantering ME—Zounds, I was neither drunk nor mad—and, to the beſt of my knowledge, I am not now in a dream—The brother, indeed, is a booby; and does not appear to be of the ſame family—hardly of the ſame ſpecies—tho' he had ſenſe enough to ſnap at the offer immediately—I remarked he did
not ſtand on ceremony—Surely I have made no miſtake in the buſineſs—s'blood if it prove ſo!—Parſon Adams the ſecond—I ſhall—hey?—Who's this?—No—no, no—it is—'tis ſhe, herſelf, in propria perſ.— (Enter Clara)—Miſs Turnbull, I moſt heartily rejoice to ſee you.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Miſs Turnbull!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Your preſence has relieved me from one of the oddeſt qualms—But the ſight of you has given me a cordial.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: What do you mean, Sir Hornet?

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Mean, my angel! why here has been a bantering, lying, aenigmatical ſon of a ſcoundrel, with a bundle of ironical, diabolical tales, railing at your beauty and accompliſhments, till egad, I began to fancy my fine-flavoured pineapple a crab.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: This is delightful!—I half ſuſpected this, from the firſt—But the miſtake is ſo pleaſant, that I cannot find in my heart to undeceive him (aſide).—There is no anſwering for the difference of taſte, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: True—Aſſes prefer thiſtles to nectarines—But yet he muſt be an aſs indeed, who could not diſtinguiſh St. Paul's from the pillory.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Taſte, Sir Hornet, is a ſort of ſhot ſilk, and has a variety of ſhades—a camelion—one ſays 'tis blue, another black, and a third is poſitive 'tis yellow—every body has it, yet nobody can tell what it is—Like ſpace, it is undeſcribable, tho' all allow there is ſuch a thing—It would be a vain attempt, therefore, for Miſs Turnbull to endeavour to pleaſe the whole world.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: An old booby—I would not give a hair of the pope's beard to pleaſe him—But how is it with Sir Harry—Is HE in raptures? Is HE dying for you?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: No, Sir—he eats and drinks as uſual, and is, for aught I can diſcover, in tolerable good health.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Is he!—an audacious dog!—in good health!—If I find him in good health, I'll piſtol him—But you miſtake the matter, perhaps—The raſcal's proud, and not willing you ſhould ſee his ſufferings—He is a ſtricken deer, and ſheds his tears in ſolitude and ſilence, mayhap—Do you diſcover no ſymptoms of the ſighing ſwain?—Does he never cut his fingers—or ſcald himſelf—or run againſt a poſt, and beg its pardon?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: No, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: I doubt he is a ſad dog—But no—no, no—I am certain he adores you—'Tis impoſſible he ſhould do otherwiſe—But there is another material point, about which I am not quite ſo certain.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: What is that, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Has he found any place in your affections?—'Tis true, he's a fine fellow—I don't mean, by that, one that is pickled in coſmetics—preſerved in muſk and marechal powder, and that will melt away, like Lot's wife, in the firſt hard ſhower—None of your fellows that are too valiant to give a woman the wall, and too witty to let her have the laſt word—But one that is—In ſhort, his own manner will beſt deſcribe what he is.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: True, Sir Hornet, but the time has been ſo ſhort.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p:
Short!—Ah, Madam, if he did not do the buſineſs with a coup d'oeil—at once—I would not give a feather of a gooſe-wing for all the arrows his Cupid has in his quiver—But come, Miſs Turnbull—I know you are above the ſilly prejudices that ordinary minds are ſwayed by—
tell me ſincerely—Has he made any impreſſion on your heart?—Is he the man?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: To ſpeak ingenuouſly, Sir Hornet, that is a point entirely undetermined, at preſent.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Undetermined!—why!—what!

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Sir Harry's perſon is engaging, his manners delightful, and his underſtanding unexceptionable.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Bravo! my dear girl!—you charm me to hear you ſay ſo!

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: I will ſay more, Sir Hornet—I find my heart intereſted in his behalf, and, ſincerely believe, I ſhall never ſee another man with whom I could be half ſo happy.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: My dear Miſs Turnbull!

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: But yet, I have too many reaſons to fear, it will be impoſſible we ſhould ever be united.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Impoſſible!

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: I do moſt firmly believe, Sir Harry poſſeſſes a thouſand virtues, but they are all tinged, diſcoloured by a failing, which if not in its own nature as erroneous as ſome other vices, is more deſtructive than any.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: I underſtand you.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: This will for ever deter a woman, who values her own peace and welfare, from cheriſhing a paſſion that muſt, in its conſequences, be ſo fatal.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: But you, my angel, will ſoon cure him of this—It is not a rooted vice—

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Permanently—or my intelligence ſays falſe—When he loſes, there is no poſſibility of perſuading him to deſiſt—the recollection of his loſs preys upon his mind, and had he the Indies, he would ſet it upon the chance of a card, the turn of a guinea, or the caſt of a die.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p:
Well, but we have hopes that Mr. Oſborne will find means to reclaim him—he is
continually with him, continually warning him, and—

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Subtlety, and refined artifice!—Mr. Oſborne, Sir Hornet, is an intereſted phyſician, and would rather encourage than cure the diſeaſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Heaven forbid!—But who informs you of this!

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Thoſe who are in the ſecret, I aſſure you, Sir—I am afraid Mr. Oſborne is a wicked man—He is—what I dare not ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: I confeſs you alarm me, tho' I hope without cauſe—Oſborne aſſumes every appearance of rigid virtue; and, if this were true, he would be the worſt of villains—However, ſuſpend your opinion awhile—I'll ſoon ſift the affair—And, in the mean time, let me beg of you to think as well of Sir Harry as your doubts will permit you.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: I ſhall do that, Sir Hornet, without an effort.

div.stage: (Sees Clara going off on the other ſide of the Stage.)

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Why, turtle!—why,—Ah! Sir Hornet—I am glad to ſee you.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Ah, ha—friend Van!—Why you look tolerably well.

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Tolerably well!—Ay, to be ſure—Why ſhould I not?

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Why ſhould you not?—Let me ſee—There are, as near as I can gueſs, about ſeventy reaſons why you ſhould not.

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Humph—Oh—what my age!—No, no—Let me tell you, Sir Hornet, I—I am not an old man.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: No!

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: No;—nor you neither.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Indeed!—I am exceedingly glad of that—and pray when did you make this diſcovery?

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Make it—why I have been making it theſe twenty years and upwards.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Oh, ho!—And how do you prove it?

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: By compariſon and reflection—I'll tell you—hold—first I'll ſhew you—what I call MY liſt of worthies—there—look at that—

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: What the devil have we here!— (reads)"PATRICK O'NEAL—married, for the ſeventh time, at the age of one hundred and thirteen—walks without a cane, never idle—children and great great grand-children, to the number of—one hundred and twenty-three!"

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: There's a fellow!—I warrant that man is alive and hearty at this moment.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Humph!—And pray, do you think to imitate this worthy, as you call him?—Will you be married ſeven times, and have a hundred and twenty-three children?

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: That's more than I can tell.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Ha!— (reads) THOMAS PAR, being aged one hundred and twenty, fell in love with Catherine Milton.

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Ay, and did penance in a white ſheet at the church door.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Humph—"HENRY JENKINS."

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Ay!—there's another!—corrected his great grandſon, a youth of ſeventy, with his own hand, for being idle.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p:
"JOHANNES DE TEMPORIBUS, or JOHN OF TIMES, armour-bearer to the emperor
Charlemagne, died, aged three hundred threeſcore and one year.

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Very well now tell me—When you compare me to Johannes de Temporibus, that is, when you compare ſixty-ſeven to three hundred threeſcore and one, can you ſay I am an old man?

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: An old man!—By the beard of Methuſelah thou art ſcarce an infant—it will be perhaps theſe five years yet before thou art perfectly a child.

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Nay, Sir Hornet, let me beg of you to be ſerious—you are an old friend, and know the world—I ſhall be glad of your advice—I ruminate on theſe things by myſelf, till I am quite melancholy—Now, if I had but ſomebody to bear half my griefs, I ſhould ſuppoſe—they would be leſſened.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Why true, as you ſay, one would imagine ſo.

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
