sp.p: Don't you think then, if I were to take a handſome—young—wife—I ſhould, perhaps, find a cure for all my ills?

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: An infallible one.

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: And this is, ſeriouſly, your opinion.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Seriouſly.

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Then tell me—You were talking with the young lady that went out as I entered.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Well! what of her.

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Is ſhe not very beautiful?

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: A divinity.

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Finely accompliſhed?

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Beyond deſcription.

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: That's right!—You are a ſenſible, diſcerning man, Sir Hornet, and I am delighted to find you approve my choice.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: YOUR choice!

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: MY choice—That is the young lady, you muſt know, to whom I intend to pay my addreſſes.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Your—your—your—your what?—

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: The Lady, I mean to marry.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! ha! ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Nay, Sir Hornet!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! ha! ha! all mad—every ſoul.

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: I don't underſtand!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Moſt reverend youth, I beg your pardon, ha! ha! ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: You ſee things in a mighty ſtrange light, Sir Hornet.—Is it any miracle that a man ſhould love a beautiful woman?

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! ha! ha!—love! Why thou'rt another AEtna—Cupid's burning mountain.—Your noſe has took fire at your fancy, and is become a beacon, to warn all young Gentlemen, of threefcore and ten, of the rocks and quickſands hid in the ſea of amorous deſires.

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Upon my word, Sir Hornet, this is exceedingly ſtrange.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!—You muſt excuſe me—What a roſy youth—Ha! ha! ha!—Hark ye, friend Vandervelt, (gravely) it's my opinion you have been bantering me rather.

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Odd—that's a good thought, (aſide)—Bantering you, why, ay to be ſure, I have—ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Oh! you have?

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Certainly, ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Didn't you perceive that before? Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: No, faith—ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: That's a good joke, ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Excellent! ha! ha! ha!
sp.stage: [The laugh continues ſome time, during which Sir Hornet imitates Vandervelt's voice and manner exactly, then ſtops ſuddenly, and looks very grave.]

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Ha! ha!—

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Now, let us be ſerious.

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: And I'll tell you a ſtory.

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Do.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: There was a certain antient perſonage, of my acquaintance, called Andrew Vandervelt—

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: What's your ſtory about me?

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Give me leave, young gentleman, and you ſhall hear—Every body imagined him to be a prudent, ſedate, grave perſon, with a moderate ſhare of common ſenſe;

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Well.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: And, as it was evident his beard was grey, his limbs palſied, his ſkin ſhriveled, and his ſinews ſhrunk;

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: How, Sir Hornet!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: They naturally concluded, he had made his will, wrote his epitaph, and beſpoke his coffin;

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Mercy upon me!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p:
But inſtead of meditating, like a pious Chriſtian, on the four laſt things, a crotchet takes him in the head, he buys a three-penny fiddle, ſcrapes a matrimonial jigg, claps a pair of horns upon his head, and curvets thro' the town,
the ſport of the mob, derided by the young, pitied by the old, and laughed at by all the world.

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Heaven deliver me, what a picture! But you forget, Sir Hornet—Didn't I explain to you, that it was only a joke?

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Oh! true—Ah, witty rogue!—well—adieu—I'll remember the joke—ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Ay, do—ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Oh! for a ſong to the tune of "Room for Cuckolds!"

div.head: SCENE I. A Chamber at Sir HARRY'S.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: MAY the everlaſting curſe of heaven conſume thoſe implements of hell—thoſe deceitful, infernal fiends—I'll never touch, never look on cards or dice again—If I ever make another bett, may all the horrors of a ruined fortune haunt me, ſleeping and waking—May I be pointed at by children, and pitied by ſharpers—Diſtraction! MAY I be—I AM already, ruined, paſt redemption.

div.stage: Enter SERVANT, and delivers a letter to Sir HARRY.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: —Um—Um—Stay, Sir (to the ſervant )—Damnation! Is it poſſible! In league with ſharpers—Who brought this letter, Sir?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: A porter, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Where is he?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Gone, Sir—he ran off round the corner in a hurry.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: You may go, Sir.

sp.speaker: Oſborne.
sp.p: You ſeem moved, Sir Harry; may I enquire the cauſe?

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: You are the cauſe, Sir.

sp.speaker: Oſborne.
sp.p: I!

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Yes, you—There, read, Sir.

sp.speaker: Oſborne.
sp.p: —Beware of a falſe friend—the perſon who gives you this caution, would ſacrifice a life to preſerve you from the deſtruction that threatens you—Mr. Oſborne is in league with Jews and ſharpers, and you are a victim to his avarice and duplicity.—So, ſo— (ſeems chagrined)—Well, Sir Harry, do you give any credit to this epiſtle?

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, you are to tell me how much, or how little, credit it deſerves.

sp.speaker: Oſborne.
sp.p: Why look you, Sir Harry, I cannot, nor I will not, enter into explanations—

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Sir!—Cannot, nor will not, enter into explanations!

sp.speaker: Oſborne.
sp.p: No, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: But I ſay, Sir, you ſhall.

sp.speaker: Oſborne.
sp.p: Shall!

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, ſhall.

sp.speaker: Oſborne.
sp.p: Ay, Sir—Who is he that SHALL make me?

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: I am he, Sir.

sp.speaker: Oſborne.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Friendſhip, honour, honeſty, ought to make you—but preſent appearances declare you void of theſe.

sp.speaker: Oſborne.
sp.p:
Preſent appearances declare you void of reaſon, Sir, otherwiſe you would remember me for one of thoſe who are not to be terrified by a loud tongue, or an angry brow—I repeat it—I will not now enter into explanations—I have
played with you, I have ſtaked MY money, and won YOURS—Would it have been diſhonourable had you won mine? I have diſpoſed of that money as I thought proper.—No matter whether with Jews or Chriſtians; and, I ſhould have ſuppoſed, your paſſion and ſuſpicion would have required better proof, than the malevolent aſperſon of an anonymous letter, ere they ought to have incited you to a quarrel with your friend.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: I beg your pardon, dear Oſborne—I am to blame—nothing but the ſeverity of my late loſſes can plead for me—I know you to be a noble-hearted, worthy fellow, and explanations, on ſuch an accuſation, are as much beneath you to give, as me to demand—forget my ſilly warmth, it is my weakneſs.

sp.speaker: Oſborne.
sp.p: Do you forget the cauſe on't, Harry, and it is forgot.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: It was madneſs—I am above ſuſpicion—'tis ungenerous—'tis damnable—pray excuſe—pray forgive me.

sp.speaker: Oſborne.
sp.p: Well, well, think no more on't—only guard againſt ſuſpicion for the future.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: No, no—it cannot be—there is an open fortitude in his manner—a boldneſs that can only reſult from innocence.

sp.speaker: Meliſſa.
sp.p:
Oh, brother, I am glad I have found you—Why did you ſend theſe troubleſome things to me? Why did not you take care of them for me? Truſt a giddy girl indeed with a parcel of bank bills—here, here, here they are—take 'em—take 'em—they will be ſafe with you—I have been in a panic, ever ſince they were in my poſſeſſion,
leſt they ſhould take wing, and fly thro' the key-hole, or ſome other unaccountable way—I am unuſed to ſuch large ſums, and don't feel happy while they are about me.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: But what am I to do with them?

sp.speaker: Meliſſa.
sp.p: Keep them till to-morrow, and then, you know, when them too, to make it the more acceptable—there are juſt twenty, of one thouſand each.—So, now I am eaſy—good bye—I am going to purchaſe a few knickknacks.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Well, but, ſiſter, Meliſſa. She's gone—flown on the light wings of innocence and happineſs—while I, depreſſed by .folly, feel a weight upon my heart, that hope itſelf cannot remove.—What is a ruined gameſter?—An ideot—who begins for his amuſement, who continues hoping to retrieve, and who is ruined before he can recollect himſelf—a wretch—deſerted, ſolitary, forlorn—aſhamed of ſociety, yet miſerable when alone—ſhunned by the proſperous—deſpiſed by the prudent—deſervedly expoſed to the poiſoned ſhafts of inſolence and envy—a byeword to the vulgar, and a jeſt to the fortunate—haunted by duns, preyed upon by uſurers, perſecuted and curſt by creditors.—Inexplicable infatuation!

div.head: SCENE another Apartment.

sp.speaker: Meliſſa.
sp.p: Mr. Turnbull, I muſt beg, Sir, you'll deſiſt—

sp.speaker: Squire.
sp.p:
Deziſt—why to be zure—I'll go and buy licenſe out o' hand—make hay while the zun
do zhine—and don't loſe the zheep for a ha'perth o'tar—what tho'—the pepper-box muſt ha' a lid—a buſhel o'words wunt vill a baſket—when the owl goes a hunting, 'tis time to light the candle.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!—If you'll permit me, my dear, I think I can relieve you from this embarraſſment.

sp.speaker: Meliſſa.
sp.p: Permit you!—I am ſure if you can, you ſhall be cannonized, and have churches erected to your memory.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: I'll talk to him in his own language—he can comprehend no other.

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: Well, vair Lady.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Well, Zir.

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: You do zee how the nail do drive—Be you to be one at bridal?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: No!—Why zo?—you'ſt be bridemaid.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: No but I wunt.

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: Wunt you?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: No—nor you'ſt not be bridegroom nother.

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: No!

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: How zo!

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Becauſe you've zold the ſkin avore you've catch'd the vox—You've reckon'd your chickens bevore they be hatch'd

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: Nay, nay—ſtop at the dike—zure, I do knaw my own mind—an' Miſs be agreed.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: But Miſs ben't agreed.

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: No!—That's a good joke—but ſhe be tho'.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: But ſhe ben't tho'.

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: But I'm zure ſhe be.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: But I'm zure ſhe ben't.

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: No!—Why Miſs—ben't you agreed?

sp.speaker: Meliſſa.
sp.p: No, Sir.

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: No!

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: You may gape, but the cherry won't drop—Too much mettle is dangerous in a blind horſe—Miſreckoning is no payment—John would a' wed, but Mary war na willing.

sp.speaker: Meliſſa.
sp.p: You ſeem ſurprized, Sir—I can only ſay, it is without reaſon—You have deceived yourſelf, in ſuppoſing ſuch an alliance poſſible, and I hope your own good ſenſe will inform you that, after this declaration, any renewal of your addreſſes to me, muſt be conſidered an inſult.

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.stage: (Stares as if he did not comprehend her for ſome time)
sp.p: An' zo then—the meaning of all this vine ſpeech, I zuppoſe, is that you wunt ha' me?

sp.speaker: Meliſſa.
sp.p: It is.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: "Make hay while the zun do zhine—Don't loſe the ſheep for a ha'p'erth of tar—A buſhel of words won't vill a baſket—When the owl goes a hunting, 'tis time to light the candle"—Your moſt obedient, gentle 'Squire—ha! ha! ha!

Zo then—It zeems I a been reckoning without my hoſt here—Well—What tho'—zoon hot zoon cold—zoon got zoon gone—Care's no cure—Zorrow won't pay a man's debts—He wanted a zinging bird, that gave a groat for a cuckoo—an' he that loſes a wife and zixpence, has loſt a teſter— (Enter Miſs Turnbull.) Why, Barbara! what be's the matter wi'thee? Where has thee been?

sp.speaker: Miſs Turnbull.
sp.p: Been!—Why I a bin wildered.

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: What loſt!

sp.speaker: Miſs Turnbull.
sp.p: Ees—an' if I had na' by good hap met wi' John, who has got direction in written hand, it were vive golden guineas to a braſs varchin I'ad been kidnapp'd, an' zent to America, among the Turks.

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: Zerve thee right—thee muſt be gadding—But I a' news vor thee—the cow'as kick't down th' milk—It's all off 'tween Miſs and I—

sp.speaker: Miſs Turnbull.
sp.p: Zure!—rabbit me an I didn't gueſs as much.

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: Ees—the nail's clench'd—Zhe and I a' zhook hands an' parted.

sp.speaker: Miſs Turnbull.
sp.p: My gracious!—What won't yo' ha' zhe?

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: No—I wunt—Her may whiſtle, but I zhan't hear—her may beckon, but I zhan't come—Catch me an' ha' me, I'm no vool—Zo, do you zee, an' you be minded to wed, zay grace an' vall too, vor I don't like your London tricks, an' zo I'ſt leave it as vaſt as I can.

sp.speaker: Miſs Turnbull.
sp.p: An' when be I to be wed?

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: Why, I do vind Zir Hornet be come, zo, when yo zee Zir Harry, yo' may zettle't—An', d'ye hear, Barbara—Don't let me vind yo' at any o'theſe ſkittiſh off an' on freaks—I a' zeen too much on 'um lately—Oh, here be Sir Harry coming—An' zo I'ſt leave you to make love your own way—I'ſt not play my ace o'trumps out yet.—

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: So—here's my good whimſical uncle's Nonpareil, as he calls her—his phoenix—All alone, Miſs Turnbull?

sp.speaker: Miſs Turnbull.
sp.p: Ees—Brother be juſt gone—A's vallen out wi Miſs, an a's plaguily frump'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Sure!

sp.speaker: Miſs Turnbull.
sp.p: Ees—A zaid, too, at yo' an I be to make love—

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: He did!

sp.speaker: Miſs Turnbull.
sp.p: Ees—and I do knaw his tricks—a'll be in a woundy rage, an I don't do as he bids me.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: What, will he be ſurly?

sp.speaker: Miſs Turnbull.
sp.p: Zurly!—a'll ſnarl worſer than our great dog Jowler at a beggar—

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: He is ill tempered then?

sp.speaker: Miſs Turnbull.
sp.p: Oh, a'll zulk vor a vortnight round—an' when a comes about again, a'll make a believe to romp—an' then a' lumps—an' gripes—an' pinches—till I am quite a weary on't.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Well you may, I think—Poor thing (aſide)—and which way are we to make love?

sp.speaker: Miſs Turnbull.
sp.p: My gracious! don't you knaw?

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: I believe I can give a gueſs—You, I ſuppoſe, are to hang down your head and titter.

sp.speaker: Miſs Turnbull.
sp.p: Ees—

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: I—hem—and look ſheepiſh.

sp.speaker: Miſs Turnbull.
sp.p: Ees.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: You gnaw your apron—I twirl my thumbs.

sp.speaker: Miſs Turnbull.
sp.p: He! he!—Ees.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: You ſay—it's a very fine day, Sir, and I anſwer, Yes, Ma'am, only it rains.

sp.speaker: Miſs Turnbull.
sp.p: He! he! he!—Ees—iveck, that be vor all the world the very moral of our country vaſhion—Oh! but here be zomebody coming—

div.stage: Enter Sir HORNET, CLARA, and VANDERVELT.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Why, Harry, you dog, what have you hid yourſelf, becauſe you would not ſee me?

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Dear Sir, I am exceedingly glad to ſee you, but it is not a quarter of an hour ſince I heard of your being in town; and I ſuppoſe, Sir, you will ſcarcely be angry at finding me in this company—

div.stage: (Vandervelt, Sir Harry, and Miſs Turnbull, walk up the ſtage in converſation.)

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Finding you in!—Zounds, what aukward cargo of ruſticity has he got there?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: A young lady from Somerſetſhire, with a tolerable good fortune, that Sir Harry, it is thought by ſome, intends to marry.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Marry!—He ſhould as ſoon marry the mummy of queen Semiramis.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: She has been ſtrongly recommended to the family, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Recommended!—By whom!

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: By one you are very intimate with, and who has very great influence with Sir Harry, as well as with yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Ay!—Who is that?—

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Pardon me there, Sir Hornet.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Certainly the fellow cannot be fooliſh enough to admire her—but I ſhall ſoon diſcover that, by what, he thinks of you—harkee, Harry!

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: I cannot, upon the whole, tell very well what to make of you—Are you thoroughly convinced that you are, at this inſtant, legally capable of making your will?

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: My will, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Ay—Are you of ſound mind?

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: I believe ſo, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Then pray tell me, now we have you face to face, what is your opinion of Miſs Turnbull?

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Sir!—That is by no means a queſtion proper to be anſwered in this company.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Pſhaw!—Damn your delicacy—Make your panegyric, and I'll bluſh for her and you too.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Sir, I have no panegyric to make.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Even ſo.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Why you impudent confounded—Have you the barefaced effrontery, with ſuch a picture before your eyes, to—

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: You have applied the torture, and my own eaſe requires confeſſion.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Humph—And ſo you—Now pray all be attentive, for Bacon's brazen head is going to utter—So you do not think Miſs Turnbull a moſt engaging—

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Why you intolerable—

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: I am concerned to ſee you ſo ſerious on the ſubject—I muſt acknowledge, that in this caſe, Sir, I have either a moſt perverſe or ſtupid imagination; and cannot, for the ſoul of me, diſcover the latent wonders in the young lady, which your better ſight has ſo diſtinct a view of.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: I am, however, exceedingly willing to try the utmoſt ſtrength of my faith, to believe as much as I can, and take the reſt for granted; provided you will not inflict the puniſhment of a wife upon my ſuperſtition.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Obliging youth! (Bows)—inflict the puniſhment of a wife upon your ſuperſtition—And ſo you think, no doubt, a wife a burthen, much too heavy for the back of ſo fine and pretty a town-made gentleman as yourfelf.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: With the addition of Miſs Turnbull's accompliſhments, I moſt undoubtedly do, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: You do—humph—Pray, moſt civil Sir—permit me to aſk—perhaps there may be ſome other lady, in this good company, to whom your profound penetration would give the preference.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: If ſuch preference could, in the leaſt make me deſerving of her, I have no ſcruple to ſay there is.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Miracle of modeſty!—there is.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Moſt aſſuredly—But, tho' to poſſeſs the lady you hint at, would make me bleſt beyond deſcription, I have never dared to declare ſo much before, becauſe I am conſcious of being unworthy of ſuch a proſuſion of charms and accompliſhments.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Generous diffidence!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Charms and—What the devil is all this!—Where am I—at ſea, or on ſhore—Have I a calenture in my brain, or is this my noſe!—They—they call you Sir Harry Portland, don't they Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: And your nephew, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir. Hornet.
sp.p: No—that's rather dubious—Well then, Mr. Harry, or Sir Harry, or what you pleaſe—You are pretty well convinced, I ſuppoſe, that I HAVE had ſome ſlight regard for you.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Perfectly, Sir, and remember it with gratitude.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p:
That remains to be proved, friend—Ever ſince your father's death, if I don't miſtake, I have been tolerably buſy, a little active,
or ſo, in forming your mind and manners, and moulding you into a ſort of being, a man might behold without bluſhing.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: It is impoſſible, Sir, I ſhould ever forget your goodneſs, tho' I am happy to be reminded of it.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: That's a lie, I believe—However, Sir—among the reſt of my cares, I was anxious to find a woman worthy of you—Nay, ſo ſolicitous was I about adjuſting preliminaries, that tho' the gout had laid an embargo upon a parcel of my fingers and toes, I reſolved to forego my own eaſe, and ſet ſail immediately, that I might convoy you ſaſe into the harbour of happineſs.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: I am very ſenſible of the benevolence of your intentions, Sir, and only wiſh you had done me the honour to—

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Well, I have only a word or two more to ſay on the ſubject—I have been an enthuſiaſtic old blockhead, 'tis true, and was fool enough to think all men had eyes; however, if you have not either the complaiſance, the wit, or the love, to hit upon ſome expedient to make your peace with Miſs Turnbull, I will never ſee, never know, never ſpeak to you again. And now, Sir, you will act as your great wiſdom ſhall direct.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p:
Indeed, Sir, I am diſtreſſed to ſee you ſo intent upon this buſineſ; I am exceedingly unhappy, to do the leaſt thing to incur your diſpleaſure—at this moment eſpecially—I have a thouſand reaſons to be diſatisfied with myſelf, and am grieved to add your anger to the lift—I would do any thing, in my power, to preſerve your friendſhip and affection; but this is too ſevere a taſk—I cannot totally forget common ſenſe—I cannot entirely command ſo delicate a paſſion, as that of love—A little time will diſcover,
whether I am ever to think of love or happineſs again!—Of this, however, I am certain—I never can poſſeſs either with Miſs Turnbull—

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Indeed youngſter! ſo reſolute!

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: What a noble fortitude!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: We ſhall ſee who will firſt read their recantation—An inſenſible blind puppy—I'll be a greater torment to him, than a beadle to a beggar—a cat to a rat—or a candle to a moth—I'll ſinge his wings—I'll plague him worſe than Moſes did the Egyptians.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Oh, Sir Hornet! you'll ſoon be of another opinion.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Never—never—never.— (Enter 'Squire behind, unperceived.) However, let him act as he will, Miſs Turnbull ſhall have no cauſe to repent her coming to London.

sp.speaker: Miſs Turnbull.
sp.p: What! will yo' take me to zee the zights?

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: Who the devil bade that gooſe cackle?

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: A curſt idiot—or I have no ſkill in phyſiognomy.

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: What, Barbara!—Ees—that her be—tho' no vool, neather—her do knaw better than to thatch her houſe wi' pancakes.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Pſhaw—Miſs Turnbull!

sp.speaker: Miſs Turnbull.
sp.p: Ees—I be here.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Again!— (takes Clara by the hand) Give me leave, I ſay, dear Miſs Turnbull, to—

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Hey! Sir Hornet!

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Why!—what!—

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: You don't take my turtle for Miſs Turnbull, ſure?

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Your turtle!—I don't know what you mean by your turtle; but I take this young lady for Miſs Turnbull, ſure.

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: You do!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Yes—I do.

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Why—what the devil—hey—why ſure—

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Ah! ha! ha! ha! ha!—This is a good joke.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: A good joke!—Why, Madam—'Squire—Zounds—

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Ah! ha! ha! ha! ha!—I would not have miſſed this for a thouſand pounds in new coined guineas.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Mr. Turnbull—Sir—Is not this your ſiſter, Sir?—

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: Ziſter!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: What thic!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: Thic Barbara!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Zounds, yes, I tell you.

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: Why no, to be zure—thic be Barbara.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!—the biter bit—the fleerer fleer'd—ha! ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Thic be Barbara—

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: Ees—Thic be Barbara—

sp.speaker: Miſs Turnbull.
sp.p: Ees—I be Barbara.

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Why, what a numſkull your nephew is, Sir Hornet!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Do you think ſo?

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: A blind, inſenſible puppy!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Is he?

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: But you'll torment him—you'll ſinge his wings—you'll plague him worſe than Moſes did the Egyptians—What a diſcovery!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Oh, yes—I have made more diſcoveries!

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Ay, what are they?

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Why the firſt is—You're an old fool—the next is—I am another—and the third is, that we are not the only two fools in company.

div.stage: Manent 'SQUIRE and Miſs TURNBULL. (they ſtand ſome time.)

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: Barbara.

sp.speaker: Miſs Turnbull.
sp.p: Ees.

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: How does thee like London?

sp.speaker: Miſs Turnbull.
sp.p: I knaw not—It do zeem a ſtrange place.

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: A ſtrange place?

sp.speaker: Miſs Turnbull.
sp.p: Ees—I do think it be.

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: Thee doſt.

sp.speaker: Miſs Turnbull.
sp.p: Ees.

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: An' zo do I—whereby, doſt zee, I'll get out on't as vaſt as I can—a pretty chace, as the man zaid that rode vifty miles a'ter a wild gooſe.—London!—an' this be London, the devil take London—come, pack up thy ribbands an' vlappets, an' make thy zel ready.

sp.speaker: Miſs Turnbull.
sp.p: Neea, zure—you wunt go zo zoon.

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: Wunt I?—an' I ſtay in thic town tonight, I'll eat it vor breakvaſt to-morrow.

sp.speaker: Miſs Turnbull.
sp.p: My gracious!

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: Come, come—don't ſtand mauxing and dawdling, but make thyzel ready.

sp.speaker: Miſs Turnbull.
sp.p: Lord!—Why I a' zeen nothing yet.

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: No—nor nothing thee zhalt zee—that I promiſe thee—zo ſtir thy ſtumps, I tell thee.

sp.speaker: Miſs Turnbull.
sp.p: My gracious!—Mun I go down into 't country again like a vool, an' ha' nothing to zay vor myzel?

sp.speaker: 'Squire.
sp.p: Why look thee, Barbara—come along—vor thee have come up like a vool, zo there can be no harm in thy going down like a vool.

div.head: SCENE I. A Library in Sir HARRY'S Houſe.

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: INDEED, Sir, you have always been the beſt of maſters to me.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: No, Timid, no—I have been a very weak, idle, fellow; and have put it out of my power to be a good maſter to any one.

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: Lackaday, Sir—don't ſay ſo—I am afraid I have been a bad ſervant—a very bad ſervant—

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Never—

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: Lackaday Sir, you don't know—you don't know—Lackaday, I thought all for the beſt—

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: You have only done what I commanded.

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: To be ſure, Sir—but, lackaday—I wiſh I durſt open my mind to him—I am terrified—he will never believe me innocent.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: My ruin is all my own work—Here, Mr. Timid, take this ring and remember me—It may be the laſt preſent I ſhall ever make you.

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: Pray don't ſay ſo, Sir—I am terrified.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: I am going to Mr. Oſborne's.

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: To Mr. Oſborne's!

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Yes—If you ſhould not ſee me tomorrow morning—if any accident ſhould happen—

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: Lackaday!

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Give the ſtate of my affairs, which I ordered you to draw up, to my uncle, and this picture to Clara, the young lady that is with him.

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: Sir! What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Oh, nothing, nothing—I'm not very well—I—a ſlight ſwimming in my head—that's all—but there is no knowing what may happen.

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: Lackaday, Sir, you terrify me—You talk like a dying man making his will.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: No, no,—not ſo—I have nothing to leave—And as to dying—men muſt die—live as long as they can, they muſt all die at laſt—

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: Shall I go for Sir Hornet, or your ſiſter, or the young lady?

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: No—no young ladies for—Oh!

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: Lackaday! my heart aches!

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: I am going to Mr. Oſborne's, preſently.

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: Lackaday—I wiſh he knew—I'll take the mortgage of the Kentiſh eſtate—Mr. Oſborne ordered me to bring it—I'll lay it open on Mr. Oſborne's table—I hope my dear maſter will ſee it—I hope he will diſcover all.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Heigho—

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: Dear Sir, don't ſigh ſo—don't look ſo—tell me what I can do to ſerve you—to oblige you—to make you happier?

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Nothing—nothing—paſt hope—paſt cure—quite, quite—

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: Lackaday!

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: A thoughtleſs—profligate—idle—diſſipated fellow—Oh my head—my head—

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: I cannot bear to ſee him ſo—I'll hurry to Mr. Oſborne's—I'll try if I can yet perſuade him to be a true friend—I'll beg, I'll pray, I'll go down on my knees—I'll do any thing.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Clara! an angel! a cherub! And what am I? Well, well, it will ſoon be all over—there will be a ſudden ſtop—a ſpeedy end— (laughing without) So happy—Heaven—Heaven increaſe your joys!—mine are for ever fled—light laughter, innocent ſmiles, and ſocial mirth are fled for ever, for ever—Oh folly!—Oh madneſs!

div.stage: Enter Sir HORNET, VANDERVELT, and CLARA (laughing.)

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Ay, ay, pray laugh, laugh heartily, I beſeech you—I deſerve, and I deſire no mercy.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: It is one of the oddeſt adventures.

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: How the deuce could you miſtake that blowzabel, Miſs Turnbull, for my turtle?

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Why true, as you ſay, friend Van: but that happens to be a blunder which I never did, nor ever could make. I ſhould as ſoon take myſelf for a king, or you for a conjuror. I only miſtook this lady to be Miſs Turnbull, not Miſs Turnbull to be this lady.

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Miſtook Miſs Turnbull and this lady, and—I don't underſtand it.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Be kind enough, Sir Hornet, to explain the matter.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: You remember, Madam, I had ſome converſation with you in the rooms at Bath.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Perſectly—

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: And you could not but perceive how forcibly I was ſtruck with your wit, beauty, and accompliſhments.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: I recollect you were very polite, Sir, and were pleaſed to ſay abundance of obliging things.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Not half ſo many as I thought, I aſſure you, Madam.

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Well ſaid, Sir Hornet——My old friend is quite enamoured with you, turtle.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, ſo I am—though I do not intend to marry the lady.

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Hem!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: My grand object, the thing that, of all others, I have moſt at heart, is to ſee my nephew, Sir Harry, happy—As for myſelf, I feel I am growing old apace, and am almoſt tired of the farce of life.

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Why ſo, Sir Hornet? I am ſure you play your part excellently.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: No, no—I am rolling down hill apace, and as the firſt ſteep declivity may precipitate me to the bottom, there are certain affairs I wiſh to ſee finiſhed, one of which is the marriage of Sir Harry.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: So the perſon you aſked concerning me, when I went out of the rooms, miſtook the queſtion, and thought you meant Miſs Turnbull?

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p:
So it appears, madam—And I was too much enraptured to ſtay to rectify miſtakes—when I negotiated the affair with 'Squire Turnbull, I ſtudiouſly avoided an interview with his ſuppoſed ſiſter, for fear the buſineſs ſhould wear a face of precipitate indelicacy.—And I thought if I could once bring you and Sir Harry together, I would leave the contingent poſſibilities to love, and the ſuperior good qualities and penetration of the parties,
which I, rationally enough, concluded could not fail to produce the deſired effect.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: But, Sir Hornet, how did it happen that you did not enquire of me myſelf who I was?

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Why faith, madam, I had been ſo particular with you, and had ſpoken ſo freely on the ſubjects of love and matrimony, that I was afraid, if I made thoſe kind of enquiries, you would miſtake the matter, perhaps, and think I wanted to make love to you in my own proper perſon. Hey, young Van—

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Heigho!

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Oh! no, Sir Hornet—I aſſure you, I had a better opinion of your underſtanding.

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Hem!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Certainly, had I been capable of ſuch a whim, I ſhould have made myſelf curs'd ridiculous, Hey, young Van—

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Beyound diſpute!

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Heigho!

div.stage: Enter TIMID, looking wild and frighted.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Heyday! What's the matter with you, old Lackaday?

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: I'm terrified—I'm terrified—I'm terrified!—

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Terrified!—what's the matter?—Zounds! why don't you ſpeak?

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: Lackaday—I can't—I can't ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Make ſigns then.

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: I'm a miſerable old man—I ran all the way to tell you—

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: Mr. Oſborne!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Mr. Oſborne! What of him?

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: Lackaday—Sir Harry!

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Heavens!—A duel.

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: I have put my truſt in man, and am deceived—I have lean'd upon a reed, and am fallen—I have ſeen the ſhadow of friendſhip, and—

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Curſelight on your metaphors; come to facts—What of Oſborne? What of Sir Harry? Where are they? What have they done? What are they doing?

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: Gambling!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: I was at Mr. Oſborne's when Sir Harry came—I was there with the mortgage of the Kentiſh eſtate.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Of what?

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: It was executed this very day—I am a miſerable old man—all loſt!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Loſt!

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: Lackaday! that's not all—I went into the next room, and heard Sir Harry go to gaming, with a gang of ſharpers that were there on purpoſe—Sir Harry had loſt every thing he had in the world—Mr. Oſborne has got all—All the mortgages of all his eſtates—I ſaw 'em—left 'em all in a box on his table.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Mortgages of all his eſtates! Perdition!—How did he get them?—How came you to know?

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: Lackaday! I am terrified—I dare not tell—I am an accomplice!—A wicked, innocent, miſerable old man.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Damnation! Order the coach there—I'll tear him to atoms—I'll rend him piecemeal—my poor boy—an intolerable villain!—Dear Madam, you don't know what I feel.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p:
Pardon me, Sir Hornet, if you knew my heart, you would not ſay ſo—I deteſt the treachery of Mr. Oſborne as much as you do; and, woman as I
am, would riſk my life to ſee it properly puniſhed.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: A ſmooth tongued, hypocritical villain, that owes his life to my boy.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Dear Sir Hornet, excuſe my weakneſs—I am in the utmoſt terror—in dread of conſequences ſtill more fatal.

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: Lackaday, Sir, ſo am I—I am terrified—Sir Harry gave me this ring for a remembrance, and bade me deliver this picture to you, Madam—

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.stage: (Looks at it, and burſts into tears.)
sp.p: —It is his own—

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: He look'd ſo melancholy, and ſo furious—He had his piſtols.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: His piſtols!—Oh for pity's ſake, Sir Hornet, let us fly.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Inſtantly.

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: I'm a miſerable old man.

div.head: SCENE II. MR. OSBORNE'S Houſe.
div.stage: Sir Harry enters exceſſively agitated, followed by Oſborne, with a brace of piſtols he had wreſted from him.

sp.speaker: Oſhorne.
sp.p: How now, Sir Harry—What is the cauſe of this ſudden phrenzy? Why expoſe your want of temper and fortitude thus to the company?—You have driven them away—they are all going—

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Oh! horror!

sp.speaker: Oſborne.
sp.p: If you muſt wreak vengeance on yourſelf, let it be a becoming one at leaſt.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Inſupportable horror!

sp.speaker: Oſborne.
sp.p: Fie, fie, recover your temper—be, or ſeem to be a man—What—You knew you were ruined before this event.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Oh, Oſborne! Oh, Meliſſa! I cannot ſpeak—I cannot utter it—I'm a wretch—a villain—the meaneſt—the worſt of villains—and infamy—eternal infamy is mine.

sp.speaker: Oſborne.
sp.p: Why, what have you done?

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Ruined you—ruin'd my ſiſter—

sp.speaker: Oſborne.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: And branded myſelf, everlaſtingly, a villain.

sp.speaker: Oſborne.
sp.p: Ruin'd me! ruin'd your ſiſter! which way?

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: The money I have loſt within—

sp.speaker: Oſborne.
sp.p: Well.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Is her's—Is your's.

sp.speaker: Oſborne.
sp.p: Mine!

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Meliſſa's—her fortune—She put it into my hand this very day—

sp.speaker: Oſborne.
sp.p: Damnation!

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Have compaſſion on me—give me the piſtols, let me at once put an end to my miſery and ſhame.

sp.speaker: Oſborne.
sp.p: Thoughtleſs, weak man! Do you think the momentary pang of death a ſufficient puniſhment for the ruin and diſtruction you have entailed upon all thoſe who have had the misfortune to love, or to be related to you? Do you think that to DIE, and to forget at once your infamy and crimes, is a compenſation for the havoc you have made with the peace and property of thoſe who were deareſt to you, who muſt LIVE to feel the effect of your vices, and bear, unjuſtly, the reproach of your abandoned conduct—

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Oh torture!

sp.speaker: Oſborne.
sp.p:
Was it not enough that you had reduced yourſelf, from affluence and honour, to contempt and beggary, but you muſt wantonly, wickedly, ſport with what was not your own;
and involve the innocent and unborn in your wretchedneſs?—Shall not your ſiſter's offspring, whom your intemperance ſhall have reduced to poverty and miſery, deteſt your memory, and imprecate curſes on your name?

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Oh hell!

div.stage: (Sir Hornet ſpeaks without, and afterwards enters, followed by Clara and Timid.)

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Where are they? which is the room? So, Mr. Lucifer—Could you decoy your friend to no other place to rob him, but your own houſe?

sp.speaker: Oſborne.
sp.p: Did you addreſs yourſelf to me, Sir Hornet.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Yes, I did, Sir Satan, and if—

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Dear Sir, forbear—I alone am the proper object of anger—of vengeance—a wretch—a deſpiſed and miſerable outcaſt; and bitterneſs and deſpair are deſervedly my portion.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: You are a dupe—a poor ſaſcinated fool—you have beheld the ſerpent's mouth open, have felt the inſluence of his poiſonous breath, yet ſtupidly dropt into his ravenous jaws, and ſung a requiem to your own deſtruction.

sp.speaker: Oſborne.
sp.p: You are liberal, Sir, of your epithets and accuſations. What do you mean by them?

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Horrible impudence! Have you not taken a vile, a raſcally advantage of the want of temper in the man, for whom you profeſt the moſt perfect friendſhip? Have you not ſtripped him of his eſtate, by the moſt villainous arts, by plotting with Jews and ſcoundrels?

sp.speaker: Oſborne.
sp.p: Your talk loud, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Oſborne! plotting! the letter then was true!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Yes, plotting!—He is the principal, the leader of the helliſh gang that has been plundering you.

sp.speaker: Oſborne
sp.p: Well, Sir!—ſuppoſe it—What then?

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: What then! Halters!—

sp.speaker: Oſborne
sp.p: Why ſo, Sir!—He has perſiſted in bringing deſtruction upon himſelf, and muſt ſuffer the effects of his obſtinacy—What crime was there in my receiving what he was reſolved to throw away. He had not been a month returned from his travels, before his paſſion for play made him the jeſt of every polite ſharper in town—They ſaw there was an eſtate to be ſcrambled for, and every one was induſtrious to obtain a ſhare—After ſquandering a part of his fortune among theſe adventurers, he engaged at play with me; and after loſing one ſum, was never eaſy till he had loſt another—Am I then to be accountable for his folly?

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Infernal treachery! Dares he avow it!

sp.speaker: Oſborne.
sp.p: Dare! Yes Sir—I dare.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Righteous heaven! Is there no peculiar, no quick vengeance for ingratitude?

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: The deeds, the annuities you have granted, the mortgages you have made, are in his poſſeſſion—he owns—he has them all—

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: He!

sp.speaker: Osborne.
sp.p: Yes, Sir—I.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Madneſs! remember and beware—remember and tremble, tho' I have no longer the fortune of Sir Harry Portland, I have ſtill Harry's ſpirit, and dare chaſtiſe inſolence and perfidy yet—

sp.speaker: Osborne.
sp.p: No doubt—The man who is raſh enough to riſk his eſtate upon the chance of a die, has generally valour enough to wiſh to cut the winners throat—Friendſhip is no protection.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p:
Friendſhip! Monſtrous proſtitution! Friendſhip! Deeds Mr. Oſborne are the beſt proofs
of friendſhip, and that, preacher will gain but little credit, who is a detected villain, while he is deſcribing the fitneſs and beauty of moral virtue.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Friendſhip! Where are the deeds, the mortgages?

sp.speaker: Osborne.
sp.p: There they are, Sir— (points to a box) They are mine—the annuities he has granted, and the mortgages he has made are mine—his effects are mine—his houſes are mine, his eſtates are mine, his notes are mine, his ALL is mine; except his poverty and ſpirit, which, as he ſays are his own.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Heavens! muſt I bear this?

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Oh! for ratſbane or hemp—

sp.speaker: Oſborne.
sp.p: Nay more, Sir (to Sir Harry) I was not only aware, but certain of my own ſuperior addreſs, or I had not been weak enough to have riſqued any part of my fortune—I have not yet acquired your heroic contempt for riches; as it was, I uſed, every art to ſtimulate and incite you to play—took every advantage, ſtudied every trick, improved every lucky chance, and rejoiced at every and all of your loſſes, 'till I had you totally in my power—I beheld diſtreſs accumulating on your head, and was happy at it; remarked the agitation of your mind, and increaſed it; ſaw the inſirmity of your temper, and aggravated it.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Damnation!—Are you a man?

sp.speaker: Oſborne.
sp.p: Try me.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Dare you give me the ſatisfaction—the revenge of a man?

sp.speaker: Oſborne
sp.p:
I'll give it you inſtantly, Sir— (As Sir Harry offers to go, Oſborne ſeizes his arm, and before he ſpeaks, his countenance changes from aſſumed anger and contempt, to the moſt tender and expreſſive friendſhip.)
There, there lies your revenge—there is your ſatisfaction—take them—remember your ſormer folly, and be happy—

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: What!

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Aſtoniſhment!

sp.speaker: Oſborne.
sp.p: Why do you ſeem ſurprized?—my heart is your's, my life is your's—I owe you every thing—A debt which never can be repaid, and never will be forgotten.—When ſinking beneath the murderous hand of villainy, it was the benevolent ardor of your ſoul, it was the intrepid valour of your arm that reſcued me.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Generous friend!

sp.speaker: Oſborne.
sp.p: In that box is contained all that I have ever won of you, and almoſt all you have ever loſt—I have become and aſſociate with ſharpers to protect you from them, and by ſacrificing a little, have preſerved the reſt. I have worn the maſk till it is become too painful, and now gladly caſt it off.— (To Sir Hornet and company) If my conduct has yet a dubious appearance—I have a witneſs that will inſtantly be credited.
sp.stage: (Goes to the chamber door and calls Meliſſa; Meliſſa enters, runs to Sir Harry, and falls upon his neck.)

sp.speaker: Meliſſa.
sp.p: My brother!

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Siſter! Oſborne!

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Oh my heart!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.stage: (after a pauſe, and endeavouring to reſtrain his tears)
sp.p: Tol der rol.

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: Lackaday!—I'm a happy old man!—He's a true friend!—he's a true friend!—I'm a happy old man!

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Can you too, ſiſter, forgive my folly? You that I have injured ſo unpardonably?

sp.speaker: Meliſſa.
sp.p:
Dear brother, you are not ſo guilty as you ſuppoſe—it was a plot upon you; you were
led into it, to ſhew you what a loſing gameſter is capable of?

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Hark you, Sir? (to Oſborne) All the mortgages and deeds are there, you ſay?

sp.speaker: Oſborne.
sp.p: All, Sir—together with whatever money elſe has, at any time, been won of him, ſince I have been concerned in this tranſaction.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: All in that box?

sp.speaker: Oſborne.
sp.p: All.

sp.speaker: Timid.
sp.p: I'm a happy old man.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: My dear uncle!

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Let me alone—Tol der rol— (Goes up to Oſborne, takes his hand, and wipes his own eyes) Will you forgive me, Oſborne? Will you? Will you forgive my boy?

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Oſborne!—I cannot ſpeak—

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: Indeed, Mr. Oſborne, I don't know how to tell you what I think—Eſteem—admiration—veneration—are poor expreſſions to convey my feelings—I have been miſtaken and to blame—I trembled for Sir Harry, I raſhly condemned you, and wrote a letter—

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Dear Madam, was that letter your's?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: It was.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: How much obliged am I to you, and to you all.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: I am ſorry, I was to blame.

sp.speaker: Oſborne.
sp.p:
Nay, Madam—Nobody was to blame—Angels are actuated by motives like your's, and if they never err, it is becauſe they have commerce with angels only.—And now, dear Harry, ſuffer me to ſay one word—Let this tranſaction be a powerful, an everlaſting memento to you.—Remember the blood that has been ſpilt in the moment of paſſion and diſtreſs, in conſequence of indulging in this ſhocking vice—Remember
the diſtracted wife, and widow's curſe, the orphans tears, the ſting of deſperation, and the red and impious hand of ſuicide; deſpiſe the folly that made the practice faſhionable; oppoſe its deſtructive courſe, and for ever ſhun, for ever abominate, the deteſtable vice of gaming.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Profeſſions of reſolution, from me, Oſborne, come with an ill grace—I am aſhamed of my folly—I deſpis'd, even while I practiſed it; but the puniſhment you have inſlicted, has been ſo judicious, ſo ſeverely generous, I think I can ſafely ſay, there is no probability of a relapſe.

sp.speaker: Sir hornet.
sp.p: Well, but Harry, turn about—look at this lady—ſurely you have not forgot Miſs Turnbull—have you?

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Your Miſs Turnbull, Sir, I ſhall never forget.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Oh! what you have heard the renowned hiſtory of my Bath adventure?

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: I have, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Well, and what ſay you to—hey my cherub—you told me, you know, you had no averſion to the fellow.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Nay, Sir Hornet, is that the part of a confidante?

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Why, yes, it is—for, as I take it, a confidante is but a kind of a go-between to bring the parties together—And here comes the blooming youth— (Enter Vandervelt) here comes Johannes de Temporibus to ſecond the motion.

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: To ſecond what motion, Sir Hornet?

sp.speaker: Sri Hornet.
sp.p: A hymeneal motion.

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Can't tell—who are the candidates?

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Harry Portland and Clara Foreſter.

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Sir Hornet, not ſo faſt!—That lady is my ward.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Yes, and may, if ſhe pleaſes, be your wife.

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Nay—I—I did not ſay ſo, Sir Hornet.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: No, but I did, young Van—but hark you— (takes him aſide) Reſign all your ſilly pretenſions peaceably, throw your worthies into the fire, and give up the lady to her lover; or you ſhall be held up, in terrorem, an object of ridicule, to frighten all the dangling, whining, old fools in chriſtendom, who are turned of threeſcore.

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Well, well, ſpeak in a lower key.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: May I be certain of your conſent then?

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Why, yes—yes—heigho:—

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Dear Madam—this worthy old Gentleman, your guardian, moſt humbly implores you would have pity upon Sir Harry.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Did you ſay ſo, papa?

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: Me! no—

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Vandervelt.
sp.p: N—not in thoſe exact words, but ſomething very like it, Turtle—heigho!—

sp.speaker: Meliſſa.
sp.p: Come, my dear Clara—Let me have the happineſs to call you ſiſter—

sp.speaker: Oſborne.
sp.p: Let me intercede, Madam.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Pſhaw—here is every body interceding, but him that can intercede moſt to the purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Forgive me, deareſt Clara—My fate is ſuſpended on your lips, and I am ſo conſcious of unworthineſs, and ſo much affected by the fear of a ſevere ſentence, that I have not power to plead for mercy.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Yes—but you have a partial, tender-hearted judge.

sp.speaker: Sir Hornet.
sp.p: Ay—"and a wiſe young judge" too—

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Well, well!—I cannot diſſemble. A generous heart, a noble mind, are ſeldom met and ſeldom merited. When happineſs like this preſents itſelf, to reject is not to deſerve it.

sp.l: INFORM me, you, at whom he ſeems to write,
Don't this man's inſolence your ſpleen excite?
Give the beau-monde impertinent advice?
Proſcribe VINGT UNE—prohibit box and dice!
Tell YOU of honour, infamy, undoing,
And—impudently preach you out of ruin?
Are cards and dice fit ſubjects for his fables?—
He'd better write a tragedy on E. O. tables?
And why, with ſo much rudeneſs and ill-nature,
'Gainſt PRIVATE vice urge acrimonious ſatire,
Since legal lotteries flouriſh every year,
And peers and pedlars run the mad career
Of public ruin, in its full extent,
And beggars game—BY ACT OF PARLIAMENT!
Nay, once in ſeven years, in full perfection,
Is play'd a game more deſp'rate, call'd, "ELECTION!"
When each grave ſenator the cauſe promotes,
And throws the main with—cogg'd and loaded votes;
When honour, conſcience, juſtice, law, religion,
Are ev'ry one, by turns, the plunder'd pigeon!
But wherefore rail at games in any ſtation?
Life is, itſelf, a game at calculation,
In which Dame Fortune gains but little thanks,
For each man ſwears HIS prizes are all blanks.
So when your am'rous lover draws for wife,
And wit and beauty link with him for life,
Tho' twice ten thouſand vows of love were paid,
To gain the charming!—dear!—angelic maid!—
Tho' conſtancy and raptures were the theme!—
Let but poſſeſſion chace the honey'd dream,
His bouncing paſſion burſts like bonfire ſquib,
And wit and beauty form—A CROOKED RIB!
The lordly huſband takes a different tone,
When once ſweet Miſs becomes "bone of his bone!"
The tender epithet, the dying leer,
Are chang'd to—"Damme, Madam, can't you hear?"
For theſe, poor authors, who their pens employ
To write down pleaſures which they can't enjoy,
You, againſt whom they aim their boldeſt ſtrokes,
Have too much NONCHALANCE to mind their jokes;
You find them ſoporifics, quite compoſing,
For all the while they're preaching, you are dozing.
Our bard, who full of antiquated notions,
Intends to cure the world by ſcenic potions,
Gravely reſolves to ſet the nation right,
If your applauſe ſhould crown his hopes to night.
